\]

**Proof.** For a \(2\times 2\) matrix, \(p_X(\lambda)=\lambda^2-(\operatorname{tr}X)\lambda+\det X\). Here \(\operatorname{tr}X=0\), so \(p_X(\lambda)=\lambda^2+\det X\), and \(p_X(X)=0\) gives \(X^2=-\det(X)I\). \(\square\)

### Lemma 2 (closed form for \(\exp X\) and its trace)
Let \(X\in\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb R)\).

- If \(\det(X)<0\), set \(s=\sqrt{-\det(X)}>0\). Then
  \[
  \exp(X)=\cosh(s)\,I+\frac{\sinh(s)}{s}\,X,\qquad \operatorname{tr}(\exp X)=2\cosh(s)\ge 2.
  \]
- If \(\det(X)=0\), then \(X^2=0\) and
  \[
  \exp(X)=I+X,\qquad \operatorname{tr}(\exp X)=2.
  \]
- If \(\det(X)>0\), set \(\theta=\sqrt{\det(X)}>0\). Then
  \[
  \exp(X)=\cos(\theta)\,I+\frac{\sin(\theta)}{\theta}\,X,\qquad \operatorname{tr}(\exp X)=2\cos(\theta)\in[-2,2].
  \]

In particular,
\[
\operatorname{tr}(\exp X)\ge -2\quad\text{for all }X\in\mathfrak g,
\]
and
\[
\operatorname{tr}(\exp X)=-2\ \Longleftrightarrow\ \exp X=-I.
\]

**Proof.** By Lemma 1, every power \(X^k\) reduces to a linear combination of \(I\) and \(X\). Grouping even and odd terms in the exponential series,
\[
\exp(X)=\left(\sum_{n\ge0}\frac{X^{2n}}{(2n)!}\right)+\left(\sum_{n\ge0}\frac{X^{2n+1}}{(2n+1)!}\right).
\]
Using \(X^{2n}=(-\det X)^n I\) and \(X^{2n+1}=(-\det X)^n X\), one gets precisely the stated \(\cosh/\sinh\) or \(\cos/\sin\) forms depending on the sign of \(\det X\) (and \(\exp(X)=I+X\) when \(X^2=0\)).

Taking traces and using \(\operatorname{tr}(X)=0\) gives \(\operatorname{tr}(\exp X)=2\cosh(s)\), \(2\), or \(2\cos(\theta)\), respectively. Hence \(\operatorname{tr}(\exp X)\ge -2\). Moreover, \(\operatorname{tr}(\exp X)=-2\) forces the \(\det(X)>0\) case with \(\cos\theta=-1\), so \(\theta=(2k+1)\pi\), which makes \(\sin\theta=0\) and thus \(\exp(X)=\cos\theta\,I=-I\). \(\square\)

### Corollary 3 (necessary condition)
If \(A\in \exp(\mathfrak g)\), then \(\operatorname{tr}(A)\ge -2\), and if \(\operatorname{tr}(A)=-2\) then \(A=-I\).

Equivalently, any \(A\in SL(2,\mathbb R)\) with \(\operatorname{tr}(A)<-2\) is **not** an exponential, and among matrices with trace \(-2\), only \(-I\) can be an exponential.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

## 2. Every \(A\in SL(2,\mathbb R)\) with \(\operatorname{tr}(A)>-2\) is an exponential

We use the standard trace classification in \(SL(2,\mathbb R)\). Let \(A\in SL(2,\mathbb R)\) and set \(t=\operatorname{tr}(A)\). The characteristic polynomial is
\[
\lambda^2-t\lambda+1.
\]

### Case 1: \(t>2\) (hyperbolic, positive eigenvalues)
Then \(\Delta=t^2-4>0\), so \(A\) has two distinct real eigenvalues \(\lambda, \lambda^{-1}\) with \(\lambda>1\). Also \(\lambda,\lambda^{-1}>0\) because their sum \(t\) is \(>0\). Hence \(A\) is diagonalizable over \(\mathbb R\): there exists \(P\in GL(2,\mathbb R)\) with
\[
P^{-1}AP=\begin{pmatrix}\lambda&0\\0&\lambda^{-1}\end{pmatrix}.
\]
Rescaling \(P\) by a scalar does not change the conjugate \(P^{-1}AP\), so we may assume \(P\in SL(2,\mathbb R)\).

Define
\[
X:=P\begin{pmatrix}\log\lambda&0\\0&-\log\lambda\end{pmatrix}P^{-1}\in\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb R).
\]
Then
\[
\exp(X)=P\begin{pmatrix}e^{\log\lambda}&0\\0&e^{-\log\lambda}\end{pmatrix}P^{-1}
=P\begin{pmatrix}\lambda&0\\0&\lambda^{-1}\end{pmatrix}P^{-1}=A.
\]
So \(A\in\exp(\mathfrak g)\).

### Case 2: \(t=2\) (parabolic/unipotent)
Then \(\Delta=0\), so the only eigenvalue is \(1\) (double). Either \(A=I\), in which case \(A=\exp(0)\), or \(A\neq I\) and \(A\) is conjugate over \(\mathbb R\) to a Jordan block:
\[
P^{-1}AP=\begin{pmatrix}1&u\\0&1\end{pmatrix}\quad (u\ne 0),
\]
again with \(P\in SL(2,\mathbb R)\) after rescaling.

Let
\[
N:=\begin{pmatrix}0&u\\0&0\end{pmatrix}\in\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb R),
\quad\text{so }N^2=0,\ \exp(N)=I+N=\begin{pmatrix}1&u\\0&1\end{pmatrix}.
\]
Then with \(X:=PNP^{-1}\in\mathfrak g\), we get \(\exp(X)=A\).

### Case 3: \(-2<t<2\) (elliptic)
Then \(\Delta=t^2-4<0\), so \(A\) has non-real complex conjugate eigenvalues \(e^{\pm i\theta}\) where \(\theta\in(0,\pi)\) is determined by
\[
t=2\cos\theta,\qquad \theta:=\arccos(t/2)\in(0,\pi).
\]
Let \(v\in\mathbb C^2\setminus\{0\}\) satisfy \(Av=e^{i\theta}v\). Writing \(v=a+ib\) with \(a,b\in\mathbb R^2\), the vectors \(a,b\) are \(\mathbb R\)-linearly independent (otherwise \(v\) would be a real eigenvector giving a real eigenvalue). In the real basis \((a,b)\), the action of \(A\) is multiplication by \(e^{i\theta}\), i.e.
\[
P^{-1}AP=R_\theta:=\begin{pmatrix}\cos\theta&-\sin\theta\\ \sin\theta&\cos\theta\end{pmatrix}
\]
for \(P=[a\ b]\in GL(2,\mathbb R)\), and again we can rescale \(P\) to lie in \(SL(2,\mathbb R)\).

Let
\[
J:=\begin{pmatrix}0&-1\\1&0\end{pmatrix}\in\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb R).
\]
Then \(\exp(\theta J)=R_\theta\). With \(X:=P(\theta J)P^{-1}\in\mathfrak g\), we get \(\exp(X)=A\).

### Conclusion of Section 2
Every \(A\in SL(2,\mathbb R)\) with \(\operatorname{tr}(A)>-2\) is in \(\exp(\mathfrak g)\). Also \(-I=\exp(\pi J)\) lies in \(\exp(\mathfrak g)\).

Combined with Corollary 3, this proves
\[
\exp(\mathfrak g)=\{A\in SL(2,\mathbb R):\operatorname{tr}(A)>-2\}\cup\{-I\}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

## 3. Determination of \(\mathcal T\)

By Corollary 3, if \(A\notin \exp(\mathfrak g)\) then \(\operatorname{tr}(A)\le -2\). Thus
\[
\mathcal T\subseteq(-\infty,-2].
\]

Conversely:

- For every \(t<-2\), choose \(s>0\) with \(t=-2\cosh s\) and let
  \[
  A=\begin{pmatrix}-e^s&0\\0&-e^{-s}\end{pmatrix}\in SL(2,\mathbb R),
  \quad \operatorname{tr}(A)=-(e^s+e^{-s})=-2\cosh s=t.
  \]
  This \(A\) cannot be an exponential, because by Lemma 2 every exponential has trace \(\ge -2\) and if trace is \(<-2\) it is impossible.

- For \(t=-2\), take for example
  \[
  A=\begin{pmatrix}-1&1\\0&-1\end{pmatrix}\in SL(2,\mathbb R),\qquad \operatorname{tr}(A)=-2.
  \]
  This \(A\neq -I\), so by Corollary 3 it cannot be an exponential. Hence \(-2\in\mathcal T\).

Therefore \((-\infty,-2]\subseteq \mathcal T\), and we conclude

\[
\boxed{\mathcal T=(-\infty,-2].}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

**Final answer.** The traces of matrices in \(SL(2,\mathbb R)\) that are **not** exponentials are exactly
\[
\mathcal T=(-\infty,-2].
\]
Equivalently, \(\exp(\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb R))\) consists of all \(A\in SL(2,\mathbb R)\) with \(\operatorname{tr}(A)>-2\) together with \(-I\), and the only obstruction at trace \(-2\) is that the nontrivial Jordan \((-1)\)-unipotents are not exponentials.

question:
Let $f: \mathbb{R} \setminus \{0, 1\} \to \mathbb{R}$ be a function satisfying the functional equation
$$ f(x) + f\left( \frac{1}{1-x} \right) = 1 + \frac{1}{x(1-x)} $$
for all $x \in \mathbb{R} \setminus \{0, 1\}$.

Find the explicit expression for $f(x)$ and determine the exact value of the integral
$$ I = \int_2^3 f(x) \, dx $$

attempts.answer:
Define the Möbius transformation
$$
T(x)=\frac1{1-x}\qquad (x\neq 1).
$$
Then
$$
T^2(x)=T(T(x))=\frac1{1-\frac1{1-x}}
=\frac1{\frac{-x}{1-x}}=-\frac{1-x}{x}=1-\frac1x,
$$
and
$$
T^3(x)=T(T^2(x))=\frac1{1-\left(1-\frac1x\right)}=\frac1{1/x}=x.
$$
So $T$ has order $3$ on $\mathbb R\setminus\{0,1\}$.

The functional equation is
$$
f(x)+f(Tx)=1+\frac1{x(1-x)} \qquad (x\neq 0,1). \tag{1}
$$
Apply it also to $Tx$ and $T^2x$:
$$
f(Tx)+f(T^2x)=1+\frac1{Tx(1-Tx)}, \tag{2}
$$
$$
f(T^2x)+f(x)=1+\frac1{T^2x(1-T^2x)}. \tag{3}
$$
Now compute the right-hand sides explicitly.

1. For $y=Tx=\frac1{1-x}$,
$$
1-y=1-\frac1{1-x}=\frac{1-x-1}{1-x}=-\frac{x}{1-x},
$$
hence
$$
y(1-y)=\frac1{1-x}\left(-\frac{x}{1-x}\right)=-\frac{x}{(1-x)^2},
\quad\Rightarrow\quad
\frac1{y(1-y)}=-\frac{(1-x)^2}{x}.
$$
So
$$
1+\frac1{Tx(1-Tx)}=1-\frac{(1-x)^2}{x}. \tag{4}
$$

2. For $z=T^2x=1-\frac1x=\frac{x-1}{x}$,
$$
1-z=1-\frac{x-1}{x}=\frac1x,
$$
hence
$$
z(1-z)=\frac{x-1}{x}\cdot\frac1x=\frac{x-1}{x^2},
\quad\Rightarrow\quad
\frac1{z(1-z)}=\frac{x^2}{x-1}.
$$
So
$$
1+\frac1{T^2x(1-T^2x)}=1+\frac{x^2}{x-1}. \tag{5}
$$

Now add (1) and (3) and subtract (2). The left-hand side becomes
$$
\bigl(f(x)+f(Tx)\bigr)+\bigl(f(T^2x)+f(x)\bigr)-\bigl(f(Tx)+f(T^2x)\bigr)=2f(x).
$$
Thus
$$
2f(x)=\left(1+\frac1{x(1-x)}\right)+\left(1+\frac{x^2}{x-1}\right)-\left(1-\frac{(1-x)^2}{x}\right).
$$
Simplify:
$$
2f(x)=1+\frac1{x(1-x)}+\frac{x^2}{x-1}+\frac{(1-x)^2}{x}.
$$
Use $\frac1{x(1-x)}=-\frac1{x(x-1)}$ and combine the two terms with denominator $x-1$:
$$
\frac{x^2}{x-1}-\frac1{x(x-1)}=\frac{x^2-\frac1x}{x-1}
=\frac{\frac{x^3-1}{x}}{x-1}
=\frac{x^3-1}{x(x-1)}
=\frac{(x-1)(x^2+x+1)}{x(x-1)}=\frac{x^2+x+1}{x}.
$$
Therefore
$$
2f(x)=1+\frac{(1-x)^2}{x}+\frac{x^2+x+1}{x}.
$$
But $\frac{(1-x)^2}{x}=\frac{x^2-2x+1}{x}=x-2+\frac1x$, and $\frac{x^2+x+1}{x}=x+1+\frac1x$. Hence
$$
2f(x)=1+\left(x-2+\frac1x\right)+\left(x+1+\frac1x\right)=2x+\frac{2}{x},
$$
so
$$
\boxed{f(x)=x+\frac1x \quad (x\in \mathbb R\setminus\{0,1\}).}
$$
(One may directly verify that this satisfies the given equation.)

---

### Integral
$$
I=\int_2^3 f(x)\,dx=\int_2^3 \left(x+\frac1x\right)dx
=\left[\frac{x^2}{2}+\ln|x|\right]_{2}^{3}
=\left(\frac{9}{2}+\ln 3\right)-\left(2+\ln 2\right).
$$
Thus
$$
\boxed{I=\frac{5}{2}+\ln\!\left(\frac{3}{2}\right).}
$$

question:
Let $\mathcal{C}$ denote the standard middle-thirds Cantor set on the interval $[0,1]$. Let $f: [0,1] \to [0,1]$ be the Cantor-Lebesgue function (also known as the Devil's Staircase). The function $f$ is the unique continuous, non-decreasing function satisfying the following functional properties:

1. $f(0)=0$ and $f(1)=1$.
2. For $x \in [0, 1/3]$, $f(x) = \frac{1}{2}f(3x)$.
3. For $x \in [1/3, 2/3]$, $f(x) = 1/2$.
4. For $x \in [2/3, 1]$, $f(x) = \frac{1}{2}(1 + f(3x-2))$.

Calculate the exact value of the integral:
$$ \mathcal{I} = \int_0^1 (f(x) - x)^2 \, dx $$

attempts.answer:
Let
$$
\mathcal I=\int_0^1 (f(x)-x)^2\,dx,
\qquad 
A:=\int_0^1 f(x)\,dx,\quad 
B:=\int_0^1 f(x)^2\,dx,\quad 
C:=\int_0^1 x f(x)\,dx.
$$
(All integrals exist since $f$ is bounded on $[0,1]$.)

## 1) Reduce $\mathcal I$ to $A,B,C$ using self-similarity

Split $[0,1]$ into thirds and use the defining relations of $f$.

### (i) On $[0,\tfrac13]$
For $x\in[0,\tfrac13]$, $f(x)=\tfrac12 f(3x)$. With $u=3x$ ($x=u/3,\,dx=du/3$),
$$
\int_0^{1/3} (f(x)-x)^2\,dx
=\frac13\int_0^1\Big(\tfrac12 f(u)-\tfrac{u}{3}\Big)^2\,du.
$$
Expand:
$$
\Big(\tfrac12 f-\tfrac{u}{3}\Big)^2=\tfrac14 f^2-\tfrac{u}{3}f+\tfrac{u^2}{9}.
$$
Hence
$$
I_1:=\int_0^{1/3} (f-x)^2
=\frac13\Big(\tfrac14 B-\tfrac13 C+\tfrac19\int_0^1 u^2\,du\Big)
=\frac{1}{12}B-\frac19 C+\frac{1}{81},
$$
since $\int_0^1 u^2\,du=\tfrac13$.

### (ii) On $[\tfrac13,\tfrac23]$
Here $f(x)=\tfrac12$. Thus
$$
I_2:=\int_{1/3}^{2/3}\Big(\tfrac12-x\Big)^2 dx
=\int_{-1/6}^{1/6} t^2\,dt=\frac{1}{324}
\quad (t=x-\tfrac12).
$$

### (iii) On $[\tfrac23,1]$
For $x\in[\tfrac23,1]$, $f(x)=\tfrac12(1+f(3x-2))$. Let $v=3x-2$ ($x=(v+2)/3,\,dx=dv/3$):
$$
I_3:=\int_{2/3}^1 (f(x)-x)^2\,dx
=\frac13\int_0^1\Big(\tfrac12(1+f(v))-\tfrac{v+2}{3}\Big)^2\,dv.
$$
Simplify the inside:
$$
\tfrac12(1+f(v))-\tfrac{v+2}{3}
=\tfrac12 f(v)-\tfrac{v}{3}-\tfrac16.
$$
Squaring and expanding gives
$$
\Big(\tfrac12 f-\tfrac{v}{3}-\tfrac16\Big)^2
=\tfrac14 f^2-\tfrac{v}{3}f-\tfrac16 f+\tfrac{v^2}{9}+\tfrac{v}{9}+\tfrac1{36}.
$$
Therefore
$$
I_3=\frac13\left(\tfrac14 B-\tfrac13 C-\tfrac16 A+\tfrac19\int_0^1 v^2\,dv+\tfrac19\int_0^1 v\,dv+\tfrac1{36}\right).
$$
Using $\int_0^1 v^2\,dv=\tfrac13,\ \int_0^1 v\,dv=\tfrac12$, the constant part is
$$
\frac13\left(\frac1{27}+\frac1{18}+\frac1{36}\right)=\frac{13}{324},
$$
so
$$
I_3=\frac{1}{12}B-\frac19 C-\frac{1}{18}A+\frac{13}{324}.
$$

### Combine
$$
\mathcal I=I_1+I_2+I_3
=\left(\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{12}\right)B+\left(-\frac19-\frac19\right)C-\frac{1}{18}A+\left(\frac{1}{81}+\frac{1}{324}+\frac{13}{324}\right).
$$
Compute the constants: $\frac{1}{81}=\frac{4}{324}$, so $\frac{4}{324}+\frac{1}{324}+\frac{13}{324}=\frac{18}{324}=\frac{1}{18}$. Hence
$$
\boxed{\ \mathcal I=\frac16 B-\frac{2}{9}C-\frac{1}{18}A+\frac{1}{18}\ }.
$$

So it remains to compute $A,B,C$.

## 2) Compute $A,B,C$ from the same self-similarity

### (a) $A=\int_0^1 f$
Split into thirds:
$$
A=\int_0^{1/3}\tfrac12 f(3x)\,dx+\int_{1/3}^{2/3}\tfrac12\,dx+\int_{2/3}^1\tfrac12(1+f(3x-2))\,dx.
$$
Substitute $u=3x$ in the first and $v=3x-2$ in the last:
$$
A=\frac16 A+\frac16+\frac16(1+A)=\frac13 A+\frac13.
$$
Thus $\frac23 A=\frac13$, so
$$
\boxed{A=\frac12.}
$$

### (b) $C=\int_0^1 x f(x)\,dx$
Again split into thirds.

On $[0,\tfrac13]$:
$$
\int_0^{1/3} x\cdot \tfrac12 f(3x)\,dx
=\int_0^1 \frac{u}{3}\cdot \frac12 f(u)\cdot \frac{du}{3}=\frac{1}{18}C.
$$

On $[\tfrac13,\tfrac23]$:
$$
\int_{1/3}^{2/3} x\cdot \tfrac12\,dx=\frac12\cdot\frac{x^2}{2}\Big|_{1/3}^{2/3}=\frac{1}{12}.
$$

On $[\tfrac23,1]$, with $v=3x-2$, $x=(v+2)/3$, $dx=dv/3$:
$$
\int_{2/3}^1 x\cdot \tfrac12(1+f(3x-2))\,dx
=\frac{1}{18}\int_0^1 (v+2)(1+f(v))\,dv.
$$
Expand:
$$
\int_0^1 (v+2)(1+f(v))\,dv=\int_0^1(v+2)\,dv+\int_0^1 (v+2)f(v)\,dv
=\frac52+(C+2A).
$$
So the last part equals $\frac{1}{18}\big(C+2A+\frac52\big)$.

Therefore
$$
C=\frac{1}{18}C+\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{18}\left(C+2A+\frac52\right)
=\frac19 C+\frac{1}{12}+\frac19 A+\frac{5}{36}.
$$
Thus
$$
\frac89 C=\frac{1}{12}+\frac19\cdot\frac12+\frac{5}{36}
=\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{18}+\frac{5}{36}
=\frac{5}{18},
$$
so
$$
\boxed{C=\frac{5}{16}.}
$$

### (c) $B=\int_0^1 f(x)^2\,dx$
Split into thirds.

On $[0,\tfrac13]$:
$$
\int_0^{1/3}\Big(\tfrac12 f(3x)\Big)^2 dx
=\int_0^1 \frac14 f(u)^2\cdot \frac{du}{3}=\frac{1}{12}B.
$$

On $[\tfrac13,\tfrac23]$:
$$
\int_{1/3}^{2/3} \Big(\tfrac12\Big)^2 dx=\frac{1}{12}.
$$

On $[\tfrac23,1]$:
$$
\int_{2/3}^1 \Big(\tfrac12(1+f(3x-2))\Big)^2 dx
=\frac{1}{12}\int_0^1 (1+f(v))^2\,dv
=\frac{1}{12}\int_0^1 (1+2f(v)+f(v)^2)\,dv
=\frac{1}{12}(1+2A+B).
$$

Hence
$$
B=\frac{1}{12}B+\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{12}(1+2A+B)
=\frac16 B+\frac16+\frac16 A.
$$
So
$$
\frac56 B=\frac16+\frac16\cdot\frac12=\frac14
\quad\Rightarrow\quad
\boxed{B=\frac{3}{10}.}
$$

## 3) Finish $\mathcal I$

Recall
$$
\mathcal I=\frac16 B-\frac{2}{9}C-\frac{1}{18}A+\frac{1}{18}.
$$
Substitute $A=\frac12,\ B=\frac{3}{10},\ C=\frac{5}{16}$:
$$
\mathcal I=\frac16\cdot\frac{3}{10}-\frac{2}{9}\cdot\frac{5}{16}-\frac{1}{18}\cdot\frac12+\frac{1}{18}
=\frac{1}{20}-\frac{5}{72}-\frac{1}{36}+\frac{1}{18}.
$$
Combine the last two terms: $-\frac{1}{36}+\frac{1}{18}=\frac{1}{36}$. Then
$$
\mathcal I=\frac{1}{20}-\frac{5}{72}+\frac{1}{36}
=\frac{1}{20}-\frac{3}{72}
=\frac{1}{20}-\frac{1}{24}
=\frac{1}{120}.
$$

$$
\boxed{\displaystyle \int_0^1 (f(x)-x)^2\,dx=\frac{1}{120}.}
$$
attempts.raw_answer:
Let
\[
\mathcal I=\int_0^1 (f(x)-x)^2\,dx,
\qquad 
A:=\int_0^1 f(x)\,dx,\quad 
B:=\int_0^1 f(x)^2\,dx,\quad 
C:=\int_0^1 x f(x)\,dx.
\]
(All integrals exist since \(f\) is bounded on \([0,1]\).)

## 1) Reduce \(\mathcal I\) to \(A,B,C\) using self-similarity

Split \([0,1]\) into thirds and use the defining relations of \(f\).

### (i) On \([0,\tfrac13]\)
For \(x\in[0,\tfrac13]\), \(f(x)=\tfrac12 f(3x)\). With \(u=3x\) (\(x=u/3,\,dx=du/3\)),
\[
\int_0^{1/3} (f(x)-x)^2\,dx
=\frac13\int_0^1\Big(\tfrac12 f(u)-\tfrac{u}{3}\Big)^2\,du.
\]
Expand:
\[
\Big(\tfrac12 f-\tfrac{u}{3}\Big)^2=\tfrac14 f^2-\tfrac{u}{3}f+\tfrac{u^2}{9}.
\]
Hence
\[
I_1:=\int_0^{1/3} (f-x)^2
=\frac13\Big(\tfrac14 B-\tfrac13 C+\tfrac19\int_0^1 u^2\,du\Big)
=\frac{1}{12}B-\frac19 C+\frac{1}{81},
\]
since \(\int_0^1 u^2\,du=\tfrac13\).

### (ii) On \([\tfrac13,\tfrac23]\)
Here \(f(x)=\tfrac12\). Thus
\[
I_2:=\int_{1/3}^{2/3}\Big(\tfrac12-x\Big)^2 dx
=\int_{-1/6}^{1/6} t^2\,dt=\frac{1}{324}
\quad (t=x-\tfrac12).
\]

### (iii) On \([\tfrac23,1]\)
For \(x\in[\tfrac23,1]\), \(f(x)=\tfrac12(1+f(3x-2))\). Let \(v=3x-2\) (\(x=(v+2)/3,\,dx=dv/3\)):
\[
I_3:=\int_{2/3}^1 (f(x)-x)^2\,dx
=\frac13\int_0^1\Big(\tfrac12(1+f(v))-\tfrac{v+2}{3}\Big)^2\,dv.
\]
Simplify the inside:
\[
\tfrac12(1+f(v))-\tfrac{v+2}{3}
=\tfrac12 f(v)-\tfrac{v}{3}-\tfrac16.
\]
Squaring and expanding gives
\[
\Big(\tfrac12 f-\tfrac{v}{3}-\tfrac16\Big)^2
=\tfrac14 f^2-\tfrac{v}{3}f-\tfrac16 f+\tfrac{v^2}{9}+\tfrac{v}{9}+\tfrac1{36}.
\]
Therefore
\[
I_3=\frac13\left(\tfrac14 B-\tfrac13 C-\tfrac16 A+\tfrac19\int_0^1 v^2\,dv+\tfrac19\int_0^1 v\,dv+\tfrac1{36}\right).
\]
Using \(\int_0^1 v^2\,dv=\tfrac13,\ \int_0^1 v\,dv=\tfrac12\), the constant part is
\[
\frac13\left(\frac1{27}+\frac1{18}+\frac1{36}\right)=\frac{13}{324},
\]
so
\[
I_3=\frac{1}{12}B-\frac19 C-\frac{1}{18}A+\frac{13}{324}.
\]

### Combine
\[
\mathcal I=I_1+I_2+I_3
=\left(\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{12}\right)B+\left(-\frac19-\frac19\right)C-\frac{1}{18}A+\left(\frac{1}{81}+\frac{1}{324}+\frac{13}{324}\right).
\]
Compute the constants: \(\frac{1}{81}=\frac{4}{324}\), so \( \frac{4}{324}+\frac{1}{324}+\frac{13}{324}=\frac{18}{324}=\frac{1}{18}\). Hence
\[
\boxed{\ \mathcal I=\frac16 B-\frac{2}{9}C-\frac{1}{18}A+\frac{1}{18}\ }.
\]

So it remains to compute \(A,B,C\).

## 2) Compute \(A,B,C\) from the same self-similarity

### (a) \(A=\int_0^1 f\)
Split into thirds:
\[
A=\int_0^{1/3}\tfrac12 f(3x)\,dx+\int_{1/3}^{2/3}\tfrac12\,dx+\int_{2/3}^1\tfrac12(1+f(3x-2))\,dx.
\]
Substitute \(u=3x\) in the first and \(v=3x-2\) in the last:
\[
A=\frac16 A+\frac16+\frac16(1+A)=\frac13 A+\frac13.
\]
Thus \(\frac23 A=\frac13\), so
\[
\boxed{A=\frac12.}
\]

### (b) \(C=\int_0^1 x f(x)\,dx\)
Again split into thirds.

On \([0,\tfrac13]\):
\[
\int_0^{1/3} x\cdot \tfrac12 f(3x)\,dx
=\int_0^1 \frac{u}{3}\cdot \frac12 f(u)\cdot \frac{du}{3}=\frac{1}{18}C.
\]

On \([\tfrac13,\tfrac23]\):
\[
\int_{1/3}^{2/3} x\cdot \tfrac12\,dx=\frac12\cdot\frac{x^2}{2}\Big|_{1/3}^{2/3}=\frac{1}{12}.
\]

On \([\tfrac23,1]\), with \(v=3x-2\), \(x=(v+2)/3\), \(dx=dv/3\):
\[
\int_{2/3}^1 x\cdot \tfrac12(1+f(3x-2))\,dx
=\frac{1}{18}\int_0^1 (v+2)(1+f(v))\,dv.
\]
Expand:
\[
\int_0^1 (v+2)(1+f(v))\,dv=\int_0^1(v+2)\,dv+\int_0^1 (v+2)f(v)\,dv
=\frac52+(C+2A).
\]
So the last part equals \(\frac{1}{18}\big(C+2A+\frac52\big)\).

Therefore
\[
C=\frac{1}{18}C+\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{18}\left(C+2A+\frac52\right)
=\frac19 C+\frac{1}{12}+\frac19 A+\frac{5}{36}.
\]
Thus
\[
\frac89 C=\frac{1}{12}+\frac19\cdot\frac12+\frac{5}{36}
=\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{18}+\frac{5}{36}
=\frac{5}{18},
\]
so
\[
\boxed{C=\frac{5}{16}.}
\]

### (c) \(B=\int_0^1 f(x)^2\,dx\)
Split into thirds.

On \([0,\tfrac13]\):
\[
\int_0^{1/3}\Big(\tfrac12 f(3x)\Big)^2 dx
=\int_0^1 \frac14 f(u)^2\cdot \frac{du}{3}=\frac{1}{12}B.
\]

On \([\tfrac13,\tfrac23]\):
\[
\int_{1/3}^{2/3} \Big(\tfrac12\Big)^2 dx=\frac{1}{12}.
\]

On \([\tfrac23,1]\):
\[
\int_{2/3}^1 \Big(\tfrac12(1+f(3x-2))\Big)^2 dx
=\frac{1}{12}\int_0^1 (1+f(v))^2\,dv
=\frac{1}{12}\int_0^1 (1+2f(v)+f(v)^2)\,dv
=\frac{1}{12}(1+2A+B).
\]

Hence
\[
B=\frac{1}{12}B+\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{12}(1+2A+B)
=\frac16 B+\frac16+\frac16 A.
\]
So
\[
\frac56 B=\frac16+\frac16\cdot\frac12=\frac14
\quad\Rightarrow\quad
\boxed{B=\frac{3}{10}.}
\]

## 3) Finish \(\mathcal I\)

Recall
\[
\mathcal I=\frac16 B-\frac{2}{9}C-\frac{1}{18}A+\frac{1}{18}.
\]
Substitute \(A=\frac12,\ B=\frac{3}{10},\ C=\frac{5}{16}\):
\[
\mathcal I=\frac16\cdot\frac{3}{10}-\frac{2}{9}\cdot\frac{5}{16}-\frac{1}{18}\cdot\frac12+\frac{1}{18}
=\frac{1}{20}-\frac{5}{72}-\frac{1}{36}+\frac{1}{18}.
\]
Combine the last two terms: \(-\frac{1}{36}+\frac{1}{18}=\frac{1}{36}\). Then
\[
\mathcal I=\frac{1}{20}-\frac{5}{72}+\frac{1}{36}
=\frac{1}{20}-\frac{3}{72}
=\frac{1}{20}-\frac{1}{24}
=\frac{1}{120}.
\]

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \int_0^1 (f(x)-x)^2\,dx=\frac{1}{120}.}
\]

question:
Compute the exact value of the following definite integral using methods from complex analysis:

$$ I = \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{\ln x}{x^2 + 2x + 2} \, dx $$

Ensure you justify your choice of contour and branch cuts, and clearly derive the residues required for the evaluation.

attempts.answer:
Let
$$
F(s):=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{x^{\,s-1}}{x^{2}+2x+2}\,dx,\qquad 0<\Re s<2.
$$
Then $F$ is analytic in the strip $0<\Re s<2$ and
$$
F'(s)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{x^{\,s-1}\ln x}{x^{2}+2x+2}\,dx
$$
by differentiation under the integral sign (justification: for $s$ in a small neighborhood of $1$, $|x^{s-1}\ln x|/(x^2+2x+2)$ is dominated by an integrable function since near $0$ it behaves like $x^{\alpha-1}|\ln x|$ with $\alpha>0$, and near $\infty$ like $x^{\beta-3}\ln x$ with $\beta<2$). Hence the desired integral is
$$
I=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\ln x}{x^{2}+2x+2}\,dx=F'(1).
$$

We now evaluate $F(s)$ using a keyhole contour.

---

## 1) Contour, branch cut, and reduction to residues

Define the branch of $\Log z$ by
$$
\Log z=\ln|z|+i\Arg z,\qquad 0<\Arg z<2\pi,
$$
so the branch cut is the **positive real axis**. Define
$$
z^{s-1}:=e^{(s-1)\Log z},
$$
which is analytic on $\mathbb{C}\setminus[0,\infty)$.

Consider the keyhole contour $C_{\varepsilon,R}$ encircling $[0,\infty)$: it runs along the upper side of $(\varepsilon,R)$, then around $|z|=R$, then back along the lower side of $(R,\varepsilon)$, then around $|z|=\varepsilon$, all counterclockwise. Let
$$
f(z):=\frac{z^{s-1}}{z^{2}+2z+2}.
$$
The only singularities of $f$ inside $C_{\varepsilon,R}$ are the simple poles of $\frac{1}{z^2+2z+2}$, i.e.
$$
z_\pm=-1\pm i.
$$

### Contributions from the rays
On the upper side of the cut, $z=x$ with $\Arg z=0$, so $z^{s-1}=x^{s-1}$ and $dz=dx$. Thus
$$
\int_{\text{upper}} f(z)\,dz=\int_{\varepsilon}^{R}\frac{x^{s-1}}{x^2+2x+2}\,dx.
$$
On the lower side, $z=xe^{2\pi i}$ with $\Arg z=2\pi$, so
$$
z^{s-1}=x^{s-1}e^{2\pi i(s-1)},\qquad dz=dx,
$$
but the contour runs from $R$ down to $\varepsilon$, hence
$$
\int_{\text{lower}} f(z)\,dz=\int_{R}^{\varepsilon}\frac{x^{s-1}e^{2\pi i(s-1)}}{x^2+2x+2}\,dx
=-e^{2\pi i(s-1)}\int_{\varepsilon}^{R}\frac{x^{s-1}}{x^2+2x+2}\,dx.
$$
Therefore the sum of the two ray integrals is
$$
\left(1-e^{2\pi i(s-1)}\right)\int_{\varepsilon}^{R}\frac{x^{s-1}}{x^2+2x+2}\,dx.
$$

### Vanishing of the circular arcs
For $|z|=R$,
$$
|f(z)|\le \frac{|z|^{\Re s-1}}{|z|^2-2|z|-2}\sim R^{\Re s-3},
$$
so the contribution is $O(R^{\Re s-2})\to 0$ as $R\to\infty$ provided $\Re s<2$.
For $|z|=\varepsilon$, $|f(z)|\sim \varepsilon^{\Re s-1}$, so the contribution is $O(\varepsilon^{\Re s})\to 0$ as $\varepsilon\to 0^+$ provided $\Re s>0$.
Thus for $0<\Re s<2$, both arcs vanish in the limit.

Taking $\varepsilon\to0$, $R\to\infty$, we get
$$
\oint_{C_{\varepsilon,R}} f(z)\,dz \to \left(1-e^{2\pi i(s-1)}\right)F(s).
$$

By the residue theorem,
$$
\oint_{C_{\varepsilon,R}} f(z)\,dz = 2\pi i\left(\operatorname{Res}(f;z_+)+\operatorname{Res}(f;z_-)\right).
$$
Hence, for $0<\Re s<2$,
$$
\left(1-e^{2\pi i(s-1)}\right)F(s)=2\pi i\sum_{\pm}\operatorname{Res}(f;z_\pm).
$$

---

## 2) Computing the residues

Since $z_\pm$ are simple poles of $1/(z^2+2z+2)$,
$$
\operatorname{Res}(f;z_\pm)=\frac{z_\pm^{\,s-1}}{(z^2+2z+2)'|_{z=z_\pm}}
=\frac{z_\pm^{\,s-1}}{2z_\pm+2}=\frac{z_\pm^{\,s-1}}{2(z_\pm+1)}.
$$
Now $z_++1=i$ and $z_-+1=-i$, so
$$
\operatorname{Res}(f;z_+)=\frac{z_+^{\,s-1}}{2i},\qquad
\operatorname{Res}(f;z_-)=\frac{z_-^{\,s-1}}{-2i}.
$$
Therefore
$$
\sum_{\pm}\operatorname{Res}(f;z_\pm)=\frac{z_+^{\,s-1}-z_-^{\,s-1}}{2i}.
$$

With our branch $0<\Arg z<2\pi$, we have
$$
z_+=-1+i=\sqrt2\,e^{i3\pi/4},\qquad z_-=-1-i=\sqrt2\,e^{i5\pi/4},
$$
so
$$
z_\pm^{\,s-1}=2^{(s-1)/2}e^{i(s-1)\Arg z_\pm}.
$$
Hence
$$
z_+^{\,s-1}-z_-^{\,s-1}
=2^{(s-1)/2}\left(e^{i(s-1)3\pi/4}-e^{i(s-1)5\pi/4}\right)
=-2i\,2^{(s-1)/2}e^{i\pi(s-1)}\sin\!\Big(\frac{\pi}{4}(s-1)\Big),
$$
and thus
$$
\sum_{\pm}\operatorname{Res}(f;z_\pm)
=-\,2^{(s-1)/2}e^{i\pi(s-1)}\sin\!\Big(\frac{\pi}{4}(s-1)\Big).
$$

Plugging into the contour identity gives
$$
\left(1-e^{2\pi i(s-1)}\right)F(s)
=2\pi i\left[-\,2^{(s-1)/2}e^{i\pi(s-1)}\sin\!\Big(\frac{\pi}{4}(s-1)\Big)\right].
$$
Since $1-e^{2\pi i(s-1)}=-2i\,e^{i\pi(s-1)}\sin(\pi(s-1))$, we simplify to
$$
F(s)=\pi\,2^{(s-1)/2}\,\frac{\sin\!\big(\frac{\pi}{4}(s-1)\big)}{\sin(\pi(s-1))},
\qquad (0<\Re s<2).
$$

---

## 3) Differentiate at $s=1$

Write $t=s-1$. Then
$$
F(1+t)=\pi\,2^{t/2}\,\frac{\sin(\frac{\pi}{4}t)}{\sin(\pi t)}.
$$
Define $r(t):=\dfrac{\sin(\frac{\pi}{4}t)}{\sin(\pi t)}$. As $t\to 0$,
$$
r(t)=\frac{\frac{\pi}{4}t+O(t^3)}{\pi t+O(t^3)}=\frac14+O(t^2),
$$
so $r(0)=\frac14$ and $r'(0)=0$.

Therefore,
$$
I=F'(1)=\left.\frac{d}{dt}F(1+t)\right|_{t=0}
=\left.\pi\left(\frac{d}{dt}2^{t/2}\right)r(t)\right|_{t=0}
+\left.\pi\,2^{t/2}r'(t)\right|_{t=0}.
$$
Since $\frac{d}{dt}2^{t/2}=2^{t/2}\frac{\ln 2}{2}$, and $r(0)=\frac14$, $r'(0)=0$, we get
$$
I=\pi\left(1\cdot\frac{\ln 2}{2}\right)\cdot\frac14
=\frac{\pi\ln 2}{8}.
$$

---

## Final answer
$$
\boxed{\displaystyle \int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\ln x}{x^{2}+2x+2}\,dx=\frac{\pi\ln 2}{8}.}
$$
attempts.raw_answer:
Let
\[
F(s):=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{x^{\,s-1}}{x^{2}+2x+2}\,dx,\qquad 0<\Re s<2.
\]
Then \(F\) is analytic in the strip \(0<\Re s<2\) and
\[
F'(s)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{x^{\,s-1}\ln x}{x^{2}+2x+2}\,dx
\]
by differentiation under the integral sign (justification: for \(s\) in a small neighborhood of \(1\), \(|x^{s-1}\ln x|/(x^2+2x+2)\) is dominated by an integrable function since near \(0\) it behaves like \(x^{\alpha-1}|\ln x|\) with \(\alpha>0\), and near \(\infty\) like \(x^{\beta-3}\ln x\) with \(\beta<2\)). Hence the desired integral is
\[
I=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\ln x}{x^{2}+2x+2}\,dx=F'(1).
\]

We now evaluate \(F(s)\) using a keyhole contour.

---

## 1) Contour, branch cut, and reduction to residues

Define the branch of \(\Log z\) by
\[
\Log z=\ln|z|+i\Arg z,\qquad 0<\Arg z<2\pi,
\]
so the branch cut is the **positive real axis**. Define
\[
z^{s-1}:=e^{(s-1)\Log z},
\]
which is analytic on \(\mathbb{C}\setminus[0,\infty)\).

Consider the keyhole contour \(C_{\varepsilon,R}\) encircling \([0,\infty)\): it runs along the upper side of \((\varepsilon,R)\), then around \(|z|=R\), then back along the lower side of \((R,\varepsilon)\), then around \(|z|=\varepsilon\), all counterclockwise. Let
\[
f(z):=\frac{z^{s-1}}{z^{2}+2z+2}.
\]
The only singularities of \(f\) inside \(C_{\varepsilon,R}\) are the simple poles of \(\frac{1}{z^2+2z+2}\), i.e.
\[
z_\pm=-1\pm i.
\]

### Contributions from the rays
On the upper side of the cut, \(z=x\) with \(\Arg z=0\), so \(z^{s-1}=x^{s-1}\) and \(dz=dx\). Thus
\[
\int_{\text{upper}} f(z)\,dz=\int_{\varepsilon}^{R}\frac{x^{s-1}}{x^2+2x+2}\,dx.
\]
On the lower side, \(z=xe^{2\pi i}\) with \(\Arg z=2\pi\), so
\[
z^{s-1}=x^{s-1}e^{2\pi i(s-1)},\qquad dz=dx,
\]
but the contour runs from \(R\) down to \(\varepsilon\), hence
\[
\int_{\text{lower}} f(z)\,dz=\int_{R}^{\varepsilon}\frac{x^{s-1}e^{2\pi i(s-1)}}{x^2+2x+2}\,dx
=-e^{2\pi i(s-1)}\int_{\varepsilon}^{R}\frac{x^{s-1}}{x^2+2x+2}\,dx.
\]
Therefore the sum of the two ray integrals is
\[
\left(1-e^{2\pi i(s-1)}\right)\int_{\varepsilon}^{R}\frac{x^{s-1}}{x^2+2x+2}\,dx.
\]

### Vanishing of the circular arcs
For \(|z|=R\),
\[
|f(z)|\le \frac{|z|^{\Re s-1}}{|z|^2-2|z|-2}\sim R^{\Re s-3},
\]
so the contribution is \(O(R^{\Re s-2})\to 0\) as \(R\to\infty\) provided \(\Re s<2\).
For \(|z|=\varepsilon\), \(|f(z)|\sim \varepsilon^{\Re s-1}\), so the contribution is \(O(\varepsilon^{\Re s})\to 0\) as \(\varepsilon\to 0^+\) provided \(\Re s>0\).
Thus for \(0<\Re s<2\), both arcs vanish in the limit.

Taking \(\varepsilon\to0\), \(R\to\infty\), we get
\[
\oint_{C_{\varepsilon,R}} f(z)\,dz \to \left(1-e^{2\pi i(s-1)}\right)F(s).
\]

By the residue theorem,
\[
\oint_{C_{\varepsilon,R}} f(z)\,dz = 2\pi i\left(\operatorname{Res}(f;z_+)+\operatorname{Res}(f;z_-)\right).
\]
Hence, for \(0<\Re s<2\),
\[
\left(1-e^{2\pi i(s-1)}\right)F(s)=2\pi i\sum_{\pm}\operatorname{Res}(f;z_\pm).
\]

---

## 2) Computing the residues

Since \(z_\pm\) are simple poles of \(1/(z^2+2z+2)\),
\[
\operatorname{Res}(f;z_\pm)=\frac{z_\pm^{\,s-1}}{(z^2+2z+2)'|_{z=z_\pm}}
=\frac{z_\pm^{\,s-1}}{2z_\pm+2}=\frac{z_\pm^{\,s-1}}{2(z_\pm+1)}.
\]
Now \(z_++1=i\) and \(z_-+1=-i\), so
\[
\operatorname{Res}(f;z_+)=\frac{z_+^{\,s-1}}{2i},\qquad
\operatorname{Res}(f;z_-)=\frac{z_-^{\,s-1}}{-2i}.
\]
Therefore
\[
\sum_{\pm}\operatorname{Res}(f;z_\pm)=\frac{z_+^{\,s-1}-z_-^{\,s-1}}{2i}.
\]

With our branch \(0<\Arg z<2\pi\), we have
\[
z_+=-1+i=\sqrt2\,e^{i3\pi/4},\qquad z_-=-1-i=\sqrt2\,e^{i5\pi/4},
\]
so
\[
z_\pm^{\,s-1}=2^{(s-1)/2}e^{i(s-1)\Arg z_\pm}.
\]
Hence
\[
z_+^{\,s-1}-z_-^{\,s-1}
=2^{(s-1)/2}\left(e^{i(s-1)3\pi/4}-e^{i(s-1)5\pi/4}\right)
=-2i\,2^{(s-1)/2}e^{i\pi(s-1)}\sin\!\Big(\frac{\pi}{4}(s-1)\Big),
\]
and thus
\[
\sum_{\pm}\operatorname{Res}(f;z_\pm)
=-\,2^{(s-1)/2}e^{i\pi(s-1)}\sin\!\Big(\frac{\pi}{4}(s-1)\Big).
\]

Plugging into the contour identity gives
\[
\left(1-e^{2\pi i(s-1)}\right)F(s)
=2\pi i\left[-\,2^{(s-1)/2}e^{i\pi(s-1)}\sin\!\Big(\frac{\pi}{4}(s-1)\Big)\right].
\]
Since \(1-e^{2\pi i(s-1)}=-2i\,e^{i\pi(s-1)}\sin(\pi(s-1))\), we simplify to
\[
F(s)=\pi\,2^{(s-1)/2}\,\frac{\sin\!\big(\frac{\pi}{4}(s-1)\big)}{\sin(\pi(s-1))},
\qquad (0<\Re s<2).
\]

---

## 3) Differentiate at \(s=1\)

Write \(t=s-1\). Then
\[
F(1+t)=\pi\,2^{t/2}\,\frac{\sin(\frac{\pi}{4}t)}{\sin(\pi t)}.
\]
Define \(r(t):=\dfrac{\sin(\frac{\pi}{4}t)}{\sin(\pi t)}\). As \(t\to 0\),
\[
r(t)=\frac{\frac{\pi}{4}t+O(t^3)}{\pi t+O(t^3)}=\frac14+O(t^2),
\]
so \(r(0)=\frac14\) and \(r'(0)=0\).

Therefore,
\[
I=F'(1)=\left.\frac{d}{dt}F(1+t)\right|_{t=0}
=\left.\pi\left(\frac{d}{dt}2^{t/2}\right)r(t)\right|_{t=0}
+\left.\pi\,2^{t/2}r'(t)\right|_{t=0}.
\]
Since \(\frac{d}{dt}2^{t/2}=2^{t/2}\frac{\ln 2}{2}\), and \(r(0)=\frac14\), \(r'(0)=0\), we get
\[
I=\pi\left(1\cdot\frac{\ln 2}{2}\right)\cdot\frac14
=\frac{\pi\ln 2}{8}.
\]

---

## Final answer
\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\ln x}{x^{2}+2x+2}\,dx=\frac{\pi\ln 2}{8}.}
\]

question:
Let $\mathbb{H} = \{(x, t) : x \in \mathbb{R}^3, t > 0\}$ be the upper half-space in $\mathbb{R}^4$. Let $u: \overline{\mathbb{H}} \to \mathbb{R}$ be the bounded continuous function that is harmonic in $\mathbb{H}$ and satisfies the boundary condition
$$ u(x, 0) = \frac{1}{(1+|x|^2)^2} $$
for all $x \in \mathbb{R}^3$, where $|x|$ denotes the Euclidean norm.

Find the exact value of the limit:
$$ L = \lim_{t \to \infty} t \left( t^3 u(0, t) - 1 \right) $$

attempts.answer:
Let $n=3$. For the upper half-space $\mathbb H=\mathbb R^{3}\times(0,\infty)$, the Poisson kernel is  
$$
P_t(z)=c_3\,\frac{t}{\bigl(|z|^2+t^2\bigr)^{(n+1)/2}}
= c_3\,\frac{t}{(|z|^2+t^2)^2},
\qquad z\in\mathbb R^3,\ t>0,
$$
where
$$
c_3=\frac{\Gamma\!\left(\frac{n+1}{2}\right)}{\pi^{(n+1)/2}}
=\frac{\Gamma(2)}{\pi^2}=\frac1{\pi^2}.
$$
Hence
$$
P_t(z)=\frac1{\pi^2}\frac{t}{(|z|^2+t^2)^2}.
$$

For bounded continuous boundary data $f$, the unique bounded harmonic extension is the Poisson integral
$$
u(x,t)=(P_t*f)(x)=\int_{\mathbb R^3}P_t(x-y)f(y)\,dy.
$$

Here
$$
f(y)=u(y,0)=\frac{1}{(1+|y|^2)^2}=\pi^2\,P_1(y).
$$
Therefore,
$$
u(x,t)=P_t*(\pi^2 P_1)(x)=\pi^2\,(P_t*P_1)(x).
$$

Now use the semigroup property of the Poisson kernel:
$$
P_t*P_s=P_{t+s}\qquad (t,s>0).
$$
A standard proof is via Fourier transform in $\mathbb R^3$: $\widehat{P_t}(\xi)=e^{-t|\xi|}$, hence
$$
\widehat{P_t*P_s}=\widehat{P_t}\,\widehat{P_s}=e^{-(t+s)|\xi|}=\widehat{P_{t+s}},
$$
so $P_t*P_s=P_{t+s}$. Thus
$$
u(x,t)=\pi^2\,P_{t+1}(x).
$$

Evaluate at $x=0$:
$$
u(0,t)=\pi^2\cdot \frac1{\pi^2}\frac{t+1}{\bigl((t+1)^2\bigr)^2}
=\frac{t+1}{(t+1)^4}=\frac{1}{(t+1)^3}.
$$

Now compute $L$:
$$
L=\lim_{t\to\infty} t\left(t^3u(0,t)-1\right)
=\lim_{t\to\infty} t\left(\frac{t^3}{(t+1)^3}-1\right).
$$
Combine the terms:
$$
\frac{t^3}{(t+1)^3}-1=\frac{t^3-(t+1)^3}{(t+1)^3}
=\frac{t^3-(t^3+3t^2+3t+1)}{(t+1)^3}
=-\frac{3t^2+3t+1}{(t+1)^3}.
$$
Therefore
$$
L=\lim_{t\to\infty} \left(-\,\frac{t(3t^2+3t+1)}{(t+1)^3}\right)
= -\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{3t^3+3t^2+t}{t^3\left(1+\frac1t\right)^3}
=-\frac{3}{1}=-3.
$$

$$
\boxed{L=-3.}
$$
attempts.raw_answer:
Let \(n=3\). For the upper half-space \(\mathbb H=\mathbb R^{3}\times(0,\infty)\), the Poisson kernel is  
\[
P_t(z)=c_3\,\frac{t}{\bigl(|z|^2+t^2\bigr)^{(n+1)/2}}
= c_3\,\frac{t}{(|z|^2+t^2)^2},
\qquad z\in\mathbb R^3,\ t>0,
\]
where
\[
c_3=\frac{\Gamma\!\left(\frac{n+1}{2}\right)}{\pi^{(n+1)/2}}
=\frac{\Gamma(2)}{\pi^2}=\frac1{\pi^2}.
\]
Hence
\[
P_t(z)=\frac1{\pi^2}\frac{t}{(|z|^2+t^2)^2}.
\]

For bounded continuous boundary data \(f\), the unique bounded harmonic extension is the Poisson integral
\[
u(x,t)=(P_t*f)(x)=\int_{\mathbb R^3}P_t(x-y)f(y)\,dy.
\]

Here
\[
f(y)=u(y,0)=\frac{1}{(1+|y|^2)^2}=\pi^2\,P_1(y).
\]
Therefore,
\[
u(x,t)=P_t*(\pi^2 P_1)(x)=\pi^2\,(P_t*P_1)(x).
\]

Now use the semigroup property of the Poisson kernel:
\[
P_t*P_s=P_{t+s}\qquad (t,s>0).
\]
A standard proof is via Fourier transform in \(\mathbb R^3\): \(\widehat{P_t}(\xi)=e^{-t|\xi|}\), hence
\[
\widehat{P_t*P_s}=\widehat{P_t}\,\widehat{P_s}=e^{-(t+s)|\xi|}=\widehat{P_{t+s}},
\]
so \(P_t*P_s=P_{t+s}\). Thus
\[
u(x,t)=\pi^2\,P_{t+1}(x).
\]

Evaluate at \(x=0\):
\[
u(0,t)=\pi^2\cdot \frac1{\pi^2}\frac{t+1}{\bigl((t+1)^2\bigr)^2}
=\frac{t+1}{(t+1)^4}=\frac{1}{(t+1)^3}.
\]

Now compute \(L\):
\[
L=\lim_{t\to\infty} t\left(t^3u(0,t)-1\right)
=\lim_{t\to\infty} t\left(\frac{t^3}{(t+1)^3}-1\right).
\]
Combine the terms:
\[
\frac{t^3}{(t+1)^3}-1=\frac{t^3-(t+1)^3}{(t+1)^3}
=\frac{t^3-(t^3+3t^2+3t+1)}{(t+1)^3}
=-\frac{3t^2+3t+1}{(t+1)^3}.
\]
Therefore
\[
L=\lim_{t\to\infty} \left(-\,\frac{t(3t^2+3t+1)}{(t+1)^3}\right)
= -\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{3t^3+3t^2+t}{t^3\left(1+\frac1t\right)^3}
=-\frac{3}{1}=-3.
\]

\[
\boxed{L=-3.}
\]

question:
Consider the domain $\Omega \subset \mathbb{C}^2$ defined by:
$$ \Omega = \left\{ (z, w) \in \mathbb{C}^2 : |z|^2 + |w|^4 < 1 \right\} $$
Let $\mathbb{B}^2 = \left\{ (z, w) \in \mathbb{C}^2 : |z|^2 + |w|^2 < 1 \right\}$ denote the standard unit ball.

1.  Compute the Levi form of the defining function $\rho(z, w) = |z|^2 + |w|^4 - 1$ at a point $p \in \partial \Omega$, restricted to the complex tangent space $T_p^{1,0}(\partial \Omega)$.
2.  Determine the set $S \subset \partial \Omega$ of points where the boundary $\partial \Omega$ is **not** strictly pseudoconvex.
3.  Prove that $\Omega$ is not biholomorphically equivalent to $\mathbb{B}^2$.
    *(Note: You may use the fact that any biholomorphic map between bounded domains in $\mathbb{C}^n$ with smooth real-analytic boundaries extends to a smooth diffeomorphism of their closures.)*

attempts.answer:
Let
$$
\rho(z,w)=|z|^2+|w|^4-1,\qquad \Omega=\{\rho<0\}\subset\mathbb C^2,
$$
so $\partial\Omega=\{\rho=0\}$. This $\rho$ is real-analytic and $\nabla\rho\neq 0$ on $\partial\Omega$ (since $\rho=0$ forces $(z,w)\neq (0,0)$, and if $z=0$ then $|w|=1$ so $\partial\rho/\partial w\neq 0$), hence $\partial\Omega$ is smooth real-analytic.

For a smooth real-valued defining function $\rho$, the Levi form at $p\in \partial\Omega$ is the Hermitian form
$$
\mathcal L_\rho(p;X)=\sum_{j,k=1}^2 \frac{\partial^2\rho}{\partial z_j\partial\bar z_k}(p)\,X_j\,\overline{X_k},
$$
defined for $X\in T^{1,0}_p(\partial\Omega)$, the complex tangent space:
$$
T^{1,0}_p(\partial\Omega)=\Bigl\{X=\sum_j X_j\frac{\partial}{\partial z_j}:\ \sum_j \rho_{z_j}(p)X_j=0\Bigr\}.
$$

---

## 1) Levi form of $\rho$ restricted to $T_p^{1,0}(\partial\Omega)$

### Step 1: compute the complex Hessian $(\rho_{j\bar k})$

Write coordinates $z_1=z,\ z_2=w$. Then
- $\rho(z,w)=z\bar z+(w\bar w)^2-1$.
- First derivatives:
  $$
  \rho_z=\bar z,\qquad \rho_w=\frac{\partial}{\partial w}(w\bar w)^2 = 2(w\bar w)\bar w=2|w|^2\bar w.
  $$
- Second derivatives:
  $$
  \rho_{z\bar z}=1,\qquad \rho_{z\bar w}=\rho_{w\bar z}=0,
  $$
  and for $\rho_{w\bar w}$:
  $$
  \rho_{w\bar w}=\frac{\partial}{\partial\bar w}\bigl(2|w|^2\bar w\bigr)
  =2\Bigl(\frac{\partial |w|^2}{\partial\bar w}\bar w+|w|^2\Bigr)
  =2\bigl(w\bar w+|w|^2\bigr)=4|w|^2.
  $$
Thus the Levi matrix is diagonal:
$$
\bigl(\rho_{j\bar k}(p)\bigr)=
\begin{pmatrix}
1 & 0\\
0 & 4|w(p)|^2
\end{pmatrix}.
$$

### Step 2: describe $T_p^{1,0}(\partial\Omega)$ and restrict

A $(1,0)$ vector $X=a\,\partial_z+b\,\partial_w$ lies in $T_p^{1,0}(\partial\Omega)$ iff
$$
\rho_z(p)\,a+\rho_w(p)\,b=0
\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
\overline{z(p)}\,a + 2|w(p)|^2\,\overline{w(p)}\,b=0.
$$
For such $X$, the Levi form is
$$
\boxed{\ \mathcal L_\rho(p;X)=|a|^2+4|w(p)|^2\,|b|^2,\qquad X=(a,b)\in T_p^{1,0}(\partial\Omega).\ }
$$

Since $T_p^{1,0}(\partial\Omega)$ is complex 1-dimensional, one convenient generator when $(z,w)\in\partial\Omega$ is
$$
L_p := \rho_z(p)\,\frac{\partial}{\partial w}-\rho_w(p)\,\frac{\partial}{\partial z}
= \overline{z(p)}\,\partial_w - 2|w(p)|^2\overline{w(p)}\,\partial_z,
$$
which satisfies $\rho_z(-\rho_w)+\rho_w(\rho_z)=0$. Plugging $a=-2|w|^2\bar w,\ b=\bar z$ into the Levi form gives
$$
\mathcal L_\rho(p;L_p)=|{-2|w|^2\bar w}|^2+4|w|^2|\bar z|^2
=4|w|^6+4|w|^2|z|^2=4|w|^2(|w|^4+|z|^2)=4|w|^2,
$$
using $|z|^2+|w|^4=1$ on $\partial\Omega$. In particular, the Levi form vanishes on $T_p^{1,0}$ iff $w(p)=0$.

---

## 2) The non–strictly pseudoconvex set $S\subset\partial\Omega$

$\partial\Omega$ is **strictly pseudoconvex at $p$** iff $\mathcal L_\rho(p;\cdot)$ is positive definite on $T_p^{1,0}(\partial\Omega)$, i.e. $\mathcal L_\rho(p;X)>0$ for all nonzero $X\in T_p^{1,0}$.

- If $w(p)\neq 0$, then $4|w(p)|^2>0$ and
  $$
  \mathcal L_\rho(p;X)=|a|^2+4|w(p)|^2|b|^2>0
  $$
  for every nonzero $(a,b)$, hence for every nonzero tangent vector $X$. So $\partial\Omega$ is strictly pseudoconvex at such $p$.

- If $w(p)=0$, then the boundary condition $|z|^2+|w|^4=1$ gives $|z(p)|=1$. The tangency condition becomes $\bar z(p)\,a=0$, so $a=0$ and tangent vectors are of the form $X=b\,\partial_w\neq 0$. But then
  $$
  \mathcal L_\rho(p;X)=|0|^2+4|w(p)|^2|b|^2=0,
  $$
  so the Levi form is degenerate and $\partial\Omega$ is not strictly pseudoconvex at $p$.

Therefore the set of non–strictly pseudoconvex boundary points is exactly
$$
\boxed{\ S=\{(z,w)\in\partial\Omega:\ w=0\}=\{(z,0)\in\mathbb C^2:\ |z|=1\}.\ }
$$

---

## 3) $\Omega$ is not biholomorphically equivalent to $\mathbb B^2$

Assume, for contradiction, that there exists a biholomorphism
$$
F:\Omega\to \mathbb B^2.
$$
Both $\Omega$ and $\mathbb B^2$ are bounded with smooth real-analytic boundary, so by the stated fact $F$ extends to a smooth diffeomorphism
$$
F:\overline{\Omega}\to \overline{\mathbb B^2},
$$
hence $F(\partial\Omega)=\partial\mathbb B^2$. Fix $p\in S$ (e.g. $p=(1,0)$), and set $q=F(p)\in\partial\mathbb B^2$.

### Key invariant: strict pseudoconvexity is preserved by such boundary maps
Let $r(u,v)=|u|^2+|v|^2-1$ be a defining function for $\mathbb B^2$. Then $r\circ F$ vanishes on $\partial\Omega$. Since both $r\circ F$ and $\rho$ are defining functions for the same smooth hypersurface near $p$ with nonvanishing differential on the boundary, there exists a smooth function $h$ near $p$ with $h(p)\neq 0$ such that
$$
r\circ F = h\,\rho
\quad\text{near }p.
$$
For any $X\in T_p^{1,0}(\partial\Omega)$ we have $\partial\rho(p)(X)=0$, and a standard product-rule computation gives
$$
\mathcal L_{h\rho}(p;X)=h(p)\,\mathcal L_\rho(p;X).
$$
Also, because $F$ is holomorphic,
$$
\mathcal L_{r\circ F}(p;X)=\mathcal L_r\bigl(q; dF_p(X)\bigr).
$$
Combining:
$$
\mathcal L_r\bigl(q; dF_p(X)\bigr)=h(p)\,\mathcal L_\rho(p;X).
$$
In particular, $\mathcal L_\rho(p;\cdot)$ is positive definite on $T_p^{1,0}$ iff $\mathcal L_r(q;\cdot)$ is positive definite on $T_q^{1,0}$ (since $h(p)\neq 0$ and $dF_p$ is an isomorphism on complex tangents).

### Contradiction
The unit sphere $\partial\mathbb B^2$ is strictly pseudoconvex everywhere: for $r(u,v)=|u|^2+|v|^2-1$,
$$
(r_{j\bar k})=\begin{pmatrix}1&0\\0&1\end{pmatrix}
\quad\Rightarrow\quad
\mathcal L_r(q;Y)=|Y_1|^2+|Y_2|^2>0\ \text{for }Y\neq 0.
$$
Thus $\partial\mathbb B^2$ is strictly pseudoconvex at $q$.

But from Part 2, at $p\in S$ the Levi form of $\rho$ vanishes on all nonzero complex tangent vectors, so $\partial\Omega$ is **not** strictly pseudoconvex at $p$.

This contradicts the invariance under $F$. Hence no such biholomorphism exists, and
$$
\boxed{\ \Omega\ \text{is not biholomorphically equivalent to}\ \mathbb B^2.\ }
$$

question:
Evaluate the following definite integral:
$$ I = \int_0^{\pi/2} x \ln(\tan x) \, dx $$
Express your answer in terms of the Riemann Zeta function, denoted as $\zeta(s)$.

attempts.answer:
The improper integral converges, since as $x\to 0^+$, $\tan x\sim x$ so $x\ln(\tan x)\sim x\ln x$ (integrable), and as $x\to (\pi/2)^-$, $\tan x\sim (\tfrac{\pi}{2}-x)^{-1}$ so $x\ln(\tan x)\sim -x\ln(\tfrac{\pi}{2}-x)$ (also integrable).

---

## 1) Fourier series for $\ln(\tan x)$

A standard Fourier expansion (valid for $0<x<\pi$) is
$$
\ln(2\sin x)= -\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{\cos(2nx)}{n},
$$
and for $0<x<\pi/2$,
$$
\ln(2\cos x)= -\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n\cos(2nx)}{n}.
$$
Subtracting gives, for $0<x<\pi/2$,
$$
\ln(\tan x)=\ln(\sin x)-\ln(\cos x)
= \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{((-1)^n-1)\cos(2nx)}{n}.
$$
Only odd $n$ contribute, and for odd $n$, $(-1)^n-1=-2$. Hence
$$
\boxed{\;\ln(\tan x)= -2\sum_{\substack{n\ge 1\\ n\ \text{odd}}}\frac{\cos(2nx)}{n}\;},\qquad 0<x<\frac{\pi}{2}.
$$

Fix $\varepsilon\in(0,\pi/4)$. On $[\varepsilon,\frac{\pi}{2}-\varepsilon]$ the series converges uniformly (Dirichlet test), so we may integrate term-by-term there.

Define
$$
I(\varepsilon)=\int_{\varepsilon}^{\frac{\pi}{2}-\varepsilon} x\ln(\tan x)\,dx.
$$
Then
$$
I(\varepsilon)= -2\sum_{\substack{n\ge 1\\ n\ \text{odd}}}\frac{1}{n}\int_{\varepsilon}^{\frac{\pi}{2}-\varepsilon} x\cos(2nx)\,dx.
$$

---

## 2) Compute $\displaystyle \int x\cos(2nx)\,dx$ and let $\varepsilon\to 0$

An antiderivative is
$$
\int x\cos(2nx)\,dx=\frac{x\sin(2nx)}{2n}+\frac{\cos(2nx)}{4n^2}.
$$
Thus
$$
\int_{\varepsilon}^{\frac{\pi}{2}-\varepsilon} x\cos(2nx)\,dx
=\left[\frac{x\sin(2nx)}{2n}+\frac{\cos(2nx)}{4n^2}\right]_{\varepsilon}^{\frac{\pi}{2}-\varepsilon}.
$$
Letting $\varepsilon\to 0^+$, the terms involving $x\sin(2nx)$ vanish (since $\sin(2n\varepsilon)=O(\varepsilon)$), and we obtain
$$
\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} x\cos(2nx)\,dx
=\frac{\cos(n\pi)-1}{4n^2}=\frac{(-1)^n-1}{4n^2}.
$$
For odd $n$, $(-1)^n-1=-2$, so
$$
\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} x\cos(2nx)\,dx=-\frac{1}{2n^2}\qquad (n\ \text{odd}).
$$
Therefore,
$$
I=\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0^+} I(\varepsilon)
=-2\sum_{\substack{n\ge 1\\ n\ \text{odd}}}\frac{1}{n}\left(-\frac{1}{2n^2}\right)
=\sum_{\substack{n\ge 1\\ n\ \text{odd}}}\frac{1}{n^3}.
$$
(The resulting series is absolutely convergent, so the limiting passage is justified once the above limit of each term is established.)

---

## 3) Express the odd zeta-sum in terms of $\zeta(3)$

$$
\sum_{\substack{n\ge 1\\ n\ \text{odd}}}\frac{1}{n^3}
=\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^3}-\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{(2n)^3}
=\zeta(3)-\frac{1}{8}\zeta(3)=\frac{7}{8}\zeta(3).
$$

---

## Final answer

$$
\boxed{\;\int_{0}^{\pi/2} x\,\ln(\tan x)\,dx=\frac{7}{8}\,\zeta(3)\;}
$$
attempts.raw_answer:
The improper integral converges, since as \(x\to 0^+\), \(\tan x\sim x\) so \(x\ln(\tan x)\sim x\ln x\) (integrable), and as \(x\to (\pi/2)^-\), \(\tan x\sim (\tfrac{\pi}{2}-x)^{-1}\) so \(x\ln(\tan x)\sim -x\ln(\tfrac{\pi}{2}-x)\) (also integrable).

\]

---

## 2) Compute \(\displaystyle \int x\cos(2nx)\,dx\) and let \(\varepsilon\to 0\)

An antiderivative is
\[
\int x\cos(2nx)\,dx=\frac{x\sin(2nx)}{2n}+\frac{\cos(2nx)}{4n^2}.
\]
Thus
\[
\int_{\varepsilon}^{\frac{\pi}{2}-\varepsilon} x\cos(2nx)\,dx
=\left[\frac{x\sin(2nx)}{2n}+\frac{\cos(2nx)}{4n^2}\right]_{\varepsilon}^{\frac{\pi}{2}-\varepsilon}.
\]
Letting \(\varepsilon\to 0^+\), the terms involving \(x\sin(2nx)\) vanish (since \(\sin(2n\varepsilon)=O(\varepsilon)\)), and we obtain
\[
\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} x\cos(2nx)\,dx
=\frac{\cos(n\pi)-1}{4n^2}=\frac{(-1)^n-1}{4n^2}.
\]
For odd \(n\), \((-1)^n-1=-2\), so
\[
\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} x\cos(2nx)\,dx=-\frac{1}{2n^2}\qquad (n\ \text{odd}).
\]
Therefore,
\[
I=\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0^+} I(\varepsilon)
=-2\sum_{\substack{n\ge 1\\ n\ \text{odd}}}\frac{1}{n}\left(-\frac{1}{2n^2}\right)
=\sum_{\substack{n\ge 1\\ n\ \text{odd}}}\frac{1}{n^3}.
\]
(The resulting series is absolutely convergent, so the limiting passage is justified once the above limit of each term is established.)

---

## 3) Express the odd zeta-sum in terms of \(\zeta(3)\)

\[
\sum_{\substack{n\ge 1\\ n\ \text{odd}}}\frac{1}{n^3}
=\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^3}-\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{(2n)^3}
=\zeta(3)-\frac{1}{8}\zeta(3)=\frac{7}{8}\zeta(3).
\]

---

## Final answer

\[
\boxed{\;\int_{0}^{\pi/2} x\,\ln(\tan x)\,dx=\frac{7}{8}\,\zeta(3)\;}
\]

question:
Find the general solution of the ordinary differential equation
$$ 4 \frac{d^2y}{dx^2} + (4e^{2x} - 1)y = 0 $$
defined for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. Express your answer in terms of elementary functions.

attempts.answer:
Divide the equation by $4$:
$$
y''+\left(e^{2x}-\frac14\right)y=0.
$$

Make the change of variable
$$
t=e^x \quad (t>0), \qquad y(x)=u(t).
$$
Then, using $dt/dx=t$,
$$
\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{du}{dt}\frac{dt}{dx}=t\,u'(t),
$$
and
$$
\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}=\frac{d}{dx}\bigl(tu'(t)\bigr)=t\,u'(t)+t\frac{d}{dx}u'(t)
=t\,u'(t)+t\left(u''(t)\frac{dt}{dx}\right)
=t\,u'(t)+t^2u''(t).
$$
Also $e^{2x}=t^2$. Substituting into the ODE gives
$$
t^2u''(t)+t u'(t)+\left(t^2-\frac14\right)u(t)=0.
$$
This is the Bessel equation
$$
t^2u''+t u'+(t^2-\nu^2)u=0
$$
with $\nu=\tfrac12$. Hence
$$
u(t)=C_1 J_{1/2}(t)+C_2 Y_{1/2}(t).
$$
For half-integer order, these are elementary:
$$
J_{1/2}(t)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi t}}\sin t,\qquad
Y_{1/2}(t)=-\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi t}}\cos t.
$$
Therefore
$$
u(t)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi t}}\Bigl(C_1\sin t - C_2\cos t\Bigr),
$$
and returning to $t=e^x$,
$$
y(x)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi e^x}}\Bigl(C_1\sin(e^x)-C_2\cos(e^x)\Bigr).
$$
Absorbing the constant factor $\sqrt{2/\pi}$ into the constants, the general real solution for $x\in\mathbb R$ can be written as
$$
\boxed{\,y(x)=e^{-x/2}\Bigl(A\sin(e^x)+B\cos(e^x)\Bigr)\,}
$$
with arbitrary constants $A,B\in\mathbb R$.

question:
Find the exact solution $u(x,t)$ to the following initial-boundary value problem for the partial differential equation:

$$ \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2} - 2 \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} $$

defined on the semi-infinite domain $x > 0$ and time $t > 0$, subject to the initial condition:
$$ u(x, 0) = 0 \quad \text{for } x > 0 $$

and the boundary conditions:
$$ u(0, t) = 1 \quad \text{for } t > 0 $$
$$ \lim_{x \to \infty} u(x, t) = 0 \quad \text{for } t > 0 $$

Express your answer in terms of the complementary error function, defined as $\text{erfc}(z) = \frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}} \int_z^\infty e^{-\eta^2} \, d\eta$.

attempts.answer:
Let $U(x,s)=\mathcal L_t\{u(x,t)\}(s)=\int_0^\infty e^{-st}u(x,t)\,dt$ for $s>0$.  
Taking the Laplace transform in $t$ of
$$
u_t=u_{xx}-2u_x,\qquad x>0,\ t>0,
$$
and using $u(x,0)=0$, gives
$$
sU=U_{xx}-2U_x \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad U_{xx}-2U_x-sU=0.
$$
The characteristic equation is
$$
r^2-2r-s=0 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad r=1\pm\sqrt{1+s}.
$$
For $s>0$, $\sqrt{1+s}>1$, so $1+\sqrt{1+s}>0$ and $1-\sqrt{1+s}<0$. The condition $u(x,t)\to0$ as $x\to\infty$ (for each fixed $t>0$) implies $U(x,s)\to0$ as $x\to\infty$, hence we must discard the growing exponential and keep only the decaying root:
$$
U(x,s)=A(s)e^{(1-\sqrt{1+s})x}.
$$
The boundary condition $u(0,t)=1$ gives $U(0,s)=\mathcal L\{1\}=1/s$, so $A(s)=1/s$. Therefore
$$
U(x,s)=\frac1s\,e^{(1-\sqrt{1+s})x}
=\frac{e^{x}}{s}\,e^{-x\sqrt{s+1}}.
$$

### Inversion lemma
For $a>0$, define
$$
f_a(t):=\frac12\Big(e^{a}\,\mathrm{erfc}\!\Big(\frac{a}{2\sqrt t}+\sqrt t\Big)+e^{-a}\,\mathrm{erfc}\!\Big(\frac{a}{2\sqrt t}-\sqrt t\Big)\Big),\qquad t>0.
$$
Differentiate $f_a$ using $\frac{d}{dz}\mathrm{erfc}(z)=-\frac{2}{\sqrt\pi}e^{-z^2}$ and the chain rule; a direct computation yields
$$
f_a'(t)=\frac{a}{2\sqrt\pi\,t^{3/2}}\,e^{-a^2/(4t)}e^{-t},\qquad t>0,
$$
and $f_a(0^+)=0$. Taking Laplace transforms,
$$
s\mathcal L\{f_a\}(s)=\mathcal L\{f_a'\}(s)
=\int_0^\infty e^{-st}\frac{a}{2\sqrt\pi\,t^{3/2}}e^{-a^2/(4t)}e^{-t}\,dt
=e^{-a\sqrt{s+1}},
$$
(using the standard Laplace identity $\mathcal L\{\frac{a}{2\sqrt\pi t^{3/2}}e^{-a^2/(4t)}\}(s)=e^{-a\sqrt s}$ and the shift $s\mapsto s+1$). Hence
$$
\mathcal L\{f_a\}(s)=\frac{1}{s}e^{-a\sqrt{s+1}}.
$$

With $a=x$, we have $\mathcal L^{-1}\left\{\frac{1}{s}e^{-x\sqrt{s+1}}\right\}=f_x(t)$, so
$$
u(x,t)=e^{x}f_x(t).
$$

### Final closed form
Thus, for $x>0,\ t>0$,
$$
\boxed{
u(x,t)=\frac12\left[
\mathrm{erfc}\!\left(\frac{x-2t}{2\sqrt t}\right)
+e^{2x}\,\mathrm{erfc}\!\left(\frac{x+2t}{2\sqrt t}\right)
\right].
}
$$

### Checks of conditions
- $u(0,t)=\frac12\big(\mathrm{erfc}(-\sqrt t)+\mathrm{erfc}(\sqrt t)\big)=\frac12\big((2-\mathrm{erfc}(\sqrt t))+\mathrm{erfc}(\sqrt t)\big)=1$.
- For fixed $x>0$, as $t\downarrow0$, both arguments $\frac{x\pm2t}{2\sqrt t}\to+\infty$, hence $u(x,0)=0$.
- For fixed $t>0$, as $x\to\infty$, $\mathrm{erfc}\big(\frac{x-2t}{2\sqrt t}\big)\to0$ and $e^{2x}\mathrm{erfc}\big(\frac{x+2t}{2\sqrt t}\big)\to0$ (Gaussian decay of $\mathrm{erfc}$), so $u(x,t)\to0$.

This $u$ is the exact solution in terms of $\mathrm{erfc}$.

question:
Let $\phi = \frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}$ be the golden ratio. Consider the dynamical system on the interval $[0, 1)$ generated by the $\beta$-transformation $T: [0, 1) \to [0, 1)$ defined by:
$$ T(x) = \phi x - \lfloor \phi x \rfloor $$
Compute the exact value of the limit
$$ L = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} T^k(x) $$
for almost every $x \in [0, 1)$ with respect to the Lebesgue measure.

attempts.answer:
Let $\beta=\phi=\frac{1+\sqrt5}{2}$. The map
$$
T(x)=\beta x-\lfloor \beta x\rfloor,\qquad x\in[0,1),
$$
is the $\beta$-transformation. It is piecewise $C^1$, expanding with constant slope $|T'|=\beta>1$, hence by the Lasota–Yorke theory it admits a unique absolutely continuous invariant probability measure $\mu$ (acip) whose density is of bounded variation; moreover $(T,\mu)$ is ergodic. Since the density is bounded above and below by positive constants, $\mu$ is **equivalent** to Lebesgue measure, so “$\mu$-a.e.” is the same as “Lebesgue-a.e.” for our purpose.

For $f(x)=x\in L^1(\mu)$, the Birkhoff ergodic theorem gives, for $\mu$-a.e. (hence Lebesgue-a.e.) $x$,
$$
\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f(T^k x)=\int_0^1 f\,d\mu=\int_0^1 x\,d\mu(x).
$$
So it remains to compute $\int_0^1 x\,d\mu$.

### 1) Invariant density for $\beta=\phi$
For a simple Parry number (i.e. the greedy $\beta$-expansion of $1$ is finite), the Parry density is explicitly
$$
h(x)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\beta^{-n}\,\mathbf 1_{[0,T^n(1))}(x),
$$
and the invariant probability density is $p(x)=\dfrac{h(x)}{\int_0^1 h}$.

Compute the orbit of $1$:
$$
T(1)=\beta-\lfloor \beta\rfloor=\beta-1=\frac1\beta,\qquad
T^2(1)=T(1/\beta)=\beta\cdot\frac1\beta-\lfloor 1\rfloor=1-1=0,
$$
so $T^n(1)=0$ for all $n\ge2$. Therefore
$$
h(x)=\mathbf 1_{[0,1)}(x)+\beta^{-1}\mathbf 1_{[0,1/\beta)}(x)
=\begin{cases}
1+\beta^{-1} & 0\le x<1/\beta,\$$2mm]
1 & 1/\beta\le x<1.
\end{cases}
$$
Using $\beta=1+\beta^{-1}$, we get $1+\beta^{-1}=\beta$, hence
$$
h(x)=\begin{cases}
\beta & 0\le x<1/\beta,\\
1 & 1/\beta\le x<1.
\end{cases}
$$
Normalize:
$$
\int_0^1 h(x)\,dx=\beta\cdot\frac1\beta+1\cdot\Bigl(1-\frac1\beta\Bigr)=1+\Bigl(1-\frac1\beta\Bigr).
$$
But $1-\frac1\beta=\frac1{\beta^2}$ (since $\beta^2=\beta+1$), so $\int_0^1 h=1+\beta^{-2}$. Thus
$$
p(x)=\frac{h(x)}{1+\beta^{-2}}.
$$

### 2) Compute the space average of $x$
Let $C=\dfrac{1}{1+\beta^{-2}}$. Then
$$
\int_0^1 x\,d\mu(x)=\int_0^1 x\,p(x)\,dx
= C\left(\beta\int_0^{1/\beta}x\,dx+\int_{1/\beta}^1 x\,dx\right).
$$
Compute the integrals:
$$
\int_0^{1/\beta}x\,dx=\frac{1}{2\beta^2},\qquad
\int_{1/\beta}^1 x\,dx=\frac12\left(1-\frac1{\beta^2}\right).
$$
Hence
$$
\int_0^1 x\,d\mu
= C\left(\beta\cdot\frac{1}{2\beta^2}+\frac12\left(1-\frac1{\beta^2}\right)\right)
= C\left(\frac{1}{2\beta}+\frac12-\frac{1}{2\beta^2}\right).
$$
Using $\frac1\beta=\beta-1$ and $\frac1{\beta^2}=2-\beta$, the bracket simplifies:
$$
\frac{1}{2\beta}+\frac12-\frac{1}{2\beta^2}
=\frac12\left(\frac1\beta+1-\frac1{\beta^2}\right)
=\frac12\left((\beta-1)+1-(2-\beta)\right)
=\frac12(2\beta-2)=\beta-1=\frac1\beta.
$$
Therefore
$$
\int_0^1 x\,d\mu = C\cdot \frac1\beta=\frac{1}{\beta(1+\beta^{-2})}
=\frac{1}{\beta+\beta^{-1}}.
$$
Finally, for $\beta=\phi$,
$$
\phi+\phi^{-1}=\frac{1+\sqrt5}{2}+\frac{\sqrt5-1}{2}=\sqrt5,
$$
so
$$
\int_0^1 x\,d\mu=\frac1{\sqrt5}.
$$

### Conclusion
By ergodicity and Birkhoff’s theorem (and $\mu\sim$ Lebesgue),
$$
\boxed{\;\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}T^k(x)=\frac1{\sqrt5}\;}
\quad\text{for Lebesgue-a.e. }x\in[0,1).
$$
attempts.raw_answer:
Let \(\beta=\phi=\frac{1+\sqrt5}{2}\). The map
\[
T(x)=\beta x-\lfloor \beta x\rfloor,\qquad x\in[0,1),
\]
is the \(\beta\)-transformation. Since the density is bounded above and below by positive constants, \(\mu\) is **equivalent** to Lebesgue measure, so “\(\mu\)-a.e.” is the same as “Lebesgue-a.e.” for our purpose.

For \(f(x)=x\in L^1(\mu)\), the Birkhoff ergodic theorem gives, for \(\mu\)-a.e. (hence Lebesgue-a.e.) \(x\),
\[

\]
So it remains to compute \(\int_0^1 x\,d\mu\).

### 1) Invariant density for \(\beta=\phi\)
For a simple Parry number (i.e. the greedy \(\beta\)-expansion of \(1\) is finite), the Parry density is explicitly

\]

Compute the orbit of \(1\):
\[

\]

\[

\end{cases}

Using \(\beta=1+\beta^{-1}\), we get \(1+\beta^{-1}=\beta\), hence

\]

\[

\]

\[

\]

### 2) Compute the space average of \(x\)
Let \(C=\dfrac{1}{1+\beta^{-2}}\). Then
\[
\int_0^1 x\,d\mu(x)=\int_0^1 x\,p(x)\,dx
= C\left(\beta\int_0^{1/\beta}x\,dx+\int_{1/\beta}^1 x\,dx\right).
\]
Compute the integrals:
\[
\int_0^{1/\beta}x\,dx=\frac{1}{2\beta^2},\qquad
\int_{1/\beta}^1 x\,dx=\frac12\left(1-\frac1{\beta^2}\right).
\]
Hence
\[
\int_0^1 x\,d\mu
= C\left(\beta\cdot\frac{1}{2\beta^2}+\frac12\left(1-\frac1{\beta^2}\right)\right)
= C\left(\frac{1}{2\beta}+\frac12-\frac{1}{2\beta^2}\right).
\]
Using \(\frac1\beta=\beta-1\) and \(\frac1{\beta^2}=2-\beta\), the bracket simplifies:
\[
\frac{1}{2\beta}+\frac12-\frac{1}{2\beta^2}
=\frac12\left(\frac1\beta+1-\frac1{\beta^2}\right)
=\frac12\left((\beta-1)+1-(2-\beta)\right)
=\frac12(2\beta-2)=\beta-1=\frac1\beta.
\]
Therefore
\[
\int_0^1 x\,d\mu = C\cdot \frac1\beta=\frac{1}{\beta(1+\beta^{-2})}
=\frac{1}{\beta+\beta^{-1}}.
\]
Finally, for \(\beta=\phi\),
\[
\phi+\phi^{-1}=\frac{1+\sqrt5}{2}+\frac{\sqrt5-1}{2}=\sqrt5,
\]

\[
\int_0^1 x\,d\mu=\frac1{\sqrt5}.
\]

### Conclusion
By ergodicity and Birkhoff’s theorem (and \(\mu\sim\) Lebesgue),
\[
\boxed{\;\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}T^k(x)=\frac1{\sqrt5}\;}
\quad\text{for Lebesgue-a.e. }x\in[0,1).
\]

question:
Determine all functions $f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ such that for all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}$:
$$ f(x^2 - y^2) = (x-y)(f(x) + f(y)) $$

attempts.answer:
Let $f:\mathbb R\to\mathbb R$ satisfy
$$
f(x^2-y^2)=(x-y)(f(x)+f(y))\qquad \forall x,y\in\mathbb R.
$$

### 1) Basic values and oddness
Set $y=x$. Then $x^2-y^2=0$ and $x-y=0$, so
$$
f(0)=0.
$$

Set $y=-x$. Then $x^2-y^2=0$ and $x-y=2x$, hence
$$
0=f(0)=2x\bigl(f(x)+f(-x)\bigr)\qquad \forall x\in\mathbb R.
$$
For $x\neq 0$ this gives $f(-x)=-f(x)$, and it also holds for $x=0$. Thus $f$ is odd:
$$
f(-x)=-f(x)\qquad \forall x\in\mathbb R.
$$

### 2) Use $y=1$ and $y=-1$
Plug $y=1$ into the equation:
$$
f(x^2-1)=(x-1)\bigl(f(x)+f(1)\bigr). \tag{1}
$$
Plug $y=-1$ into the equation:
$$
f(x^2-1)=(x+1)\bigl(f(x)+f(-1)\bigr). \tag{2}
$$
By oddness, $f(-1)=-f(1)$. Substitute into (2):
$$
f(x^2-1)=(x+1)\bigl(f(x)-f(1)\bigr). \tag{3}
$$
Now (1) and (3) have the same left-hand side, so their right-hand sides are equal:
$$
(x-1)\bigl(f(x)+f(1)\bigr)=(x+1)\bigl(f(x)-f(1)\bigr)\qquad \forall x\in\mathbb R.
$$
Expand and simplify:
$$
(x-1)f(x)+(x-1)f(1)=(x+1)f(x)-(x+1)f(1),
$$
$$
\bigl((x-1)-(x+1)\bigr)f(x)+\bigl((x-1)+(x+1)\bigr)f(1)=0,
$$
$$
-2f(x)+2x\,f(1)=0.
$$
Hence
$$
f(x)=x\,f(1)\qquad \forall x\in\mathbb R.
$$
So $f$ must be linear of the form $f(x)=cx$, where $c=f(1)\in\mathbb R$.

### 3) Verification
Let $f(x)=cx$. Then
$$
f(x^2-y^2)=c(x^2-y^2)=c(x-y)(x+y),
$$
and
$$
(x-y)(f(x)+f(y))=(x-y)(cx+cy)=c(x-y)(x+y),
$$
so the equation holds for all $x,y$.

### Conclusion
All solutions are
$$
\boxed{f(x)=cx\ \text{ for some constant }c\in\mathbb R.}
$$
attempts.raw_answer:
Let \(f:\mathbb R\to\mathbb R\) satisfy
\[
f(x^2-y^2)=(x-y)(f(x)+f(y))\qquad \forall x,y\in\mathbb R.
\]

### 1) Basic values and oddness
Set \(y=x\). Then \(x^2-y^2=0\) and \(x-y=0\), so
\[
f(0)=0.
\]

Set \(y=-x\). Then \(x^2-y^2=0\) and \(x-y=2x\), hence
\[
0=f(0)=2x\bigl(f(x)+f(-x)\bigr)\qquad \forall x\in\mathbb R.
\]
For \(x\neq 0\) this gives \(f(-x)=-f(x)\), and it also holds for \(x=0\). Thus \(f\) is odd:
\[
f(-x)=-f(x)\qquad \forall x\in\mathbb R.
\]

### 2) Use \(y=1\) and \(y=-1\)
Plug \(y=1\) into the equation:
\[
f(x^2-1)=(x-1)\bigl(f(x)+f(1)\bigr). \tag{1}
\]
Plug \(y=-1\) into the equation:
\[
f(x^2-1)=(x+1)\bigl(f(x)+f(-1)\bigr). \tag{2}
\]
By oddness, \(f(-1)=-f(1)\). Substitute into (2):
\[
f(x^2-1)=(x+1)\bigl(f(x)-f(1)\bigr). \tag{3}
\]
Now (1) and (3) have the same left-hand side, so their right-hand sides are equal:
\[
(x-1)\bigl(f(x)+f(1)\bigr)=(x+1)\bigl(f(x)-f(1)\bigr)\qquad \forall x\in\mathbb R.
\]
Expand and simplify:
\[
(x-1)f(x)+(x-1)f(1)=(x+1)f(x)-(x+1)f(1),
\]
\[
\bigl((x-1)-(x+1)\bigr)f(x)+\bigl((x-1)+(x+1)\bigr)f(1)=0,
\]
\[
-2f(x)+2x\,f(1)=0.
\]
Hence
\[
f(x)=x\,f(1)\qquad \forall x\in\mathbb R.
\]
So \(f\) must be linear of the form \(f(x)=cx\), where \(c=f(1)\in\mathbb R\).

### 3) Verification
Let \(f(x)=cx\). Then
\[
f(x^2-y^2)=c(x^2-y^2)=c(x-y)(x+y),
\]
and
\[
(x-y)(f(x)+f(y))=(x-y)(cx+cy)=c(x-y)(x+y),
\]
so the equation holds for all \(x,y\).

### Conclusion
All solutions are
\[
\boxed{f(x)=cx\ \text{ for some constant }c\in\mathbb R.}
\]

question:
Determine the exact value of the infinite series:
$$ \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{2^n}{n^2 \binom{2n}{n}} $$

attempts.answer:
Let  
$$
S:=\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{2^n}{n^2\binom{2n}{n}}.
$$

### 1) Convert the binomial factor to a Beta–integral
Using
$$
\binom{2n}{n}=\frac{(2n)!}{(n!)^2}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\frac1{\binom{2n}{n}}=\frac{(n!)^2}{(2n)!},
$$
and the Beta identity
$$
\int_0^1 x^n(1-x)^n\,dx=B(n+1,n+1)=\frac{(n!)^2}{(2n+1)!},
$$
we get
$$
\frac{1}{\binom{2n}{n}}=(2n+1)\int_0^1 x^n(1-x)^n\,dx.
$$
Hence, termwise (all terms are nonnegative, so Tonelli applies),
$$
S=\int_0^1 \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{2^n(2n+1)}{n^2}\bigl(x(1-x)\bigr)^n\,dx
=\int_0^1 \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{2n+1}{n^2}\,y^n\,dx,
$$
where $y=2x(1-x)\in[0,\tfrac12]$.

Now note
$$
\frac{2n+1}{n^2}=\frac{2}{n}+\frac1{n^2},
$$
so for $|y|<1$ (here $0\le y\le \tfrac12$),
$$
\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{2n+1}{n^2}y^n
=2\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{y^n}{n}+\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{y^n}{n^2}
=-2\ln(1-y)+\operatorname{Li}_2(y).
$$
Therefore
$$
S=\int_0^1\Bigl(-2\ln\bigl(1-2x(1-x)\bigr)+\operatorname{Li}_2\bigl(2x(1-x)\bigr)\Bigr)\,dx.
$$

### 2) Simplify the integral to a classical form
Let $x=\frac{1-t}{2}$ so $dx=\frac{dt}{2}$, $t\in[-1,1]$, and
$$
2x(1-x)=\frac{1-t^2}{2},\qquad 1-2x(1-x)=\frac{1+t^2}{2}.
$$
Using evenness in $t$, this becomes
$$
S=\int_0^1\left(\operatorname{Li}_2\!\left(\frac{1-t^2}{2}\right)-2\ln\!\left(\frac{1+t^2}{2}\right)\right)\,dt.
$$
Write this as
$$
S=I-2J,
\quad
I:=\int_0^1 \operatorname{Li}_2\!\left(\frac{1-t^2}{2}\right)\,dt,
\quad
J:=\int_0^1 \ln\!\left(\frac{1+t^2}{2}\right)\,dt.
$$

Compute $J$:
$$
J=\int_0^1 \ln(1+t^2)\,dt-\ln2.
$$
Integration by parts gives
$$
\int_0^1\ln(1+t^2)\,dt=\Bigl[t\ln(1+t^2)\Bigr]_0^1-\int_0^1 \frac{2t^2}{1+t^2}\,dt
=\ln2-2\int_0^1\left(1-\frac1{1+t^2}\right)dt
$$
$$
=\ln2-2\left(1-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)=\ln2-2+\frac{\pi}{2}.
$$
Thus $J=\frac{\pi}{2}-2$, so $-2J=4-\pi$, hence
$$
S=I+4-\pi.
$$

Now use $\operatorname{Li}_2(z)=-\int_0^z \frac{\ln(1-s)}{s}\,ds$. Since $-\ln(1-s)/s\ge 0$ on $(0,1/2]$, Tonelli allows swapping integrals:
$$
I=-\int_0^1\int_0^{(1-t^2)/2}\frac{\ln(1-s)}{s}\,ds\,dt
=-\int_0^{1/2}\frac{\ln(1-s)}{s}\left(\int_0^{\sqrt{1-2s}}dt\right)ds
$$
$$
=-\int_0^{1/2}\frac{\ln(1-s)}{s}\sqrt{1-2s}\,ds.
$$
Let $s=\frac{1-u^2}{2}$ ($u\in[0,1]$), $ds=-u\,du$, $\sqrt{1-2s}=u$, and $1-s=\frac{1+u^2}{2}$. Then
$$
I=-\int_1^0 \frac{\ln\!\left(\frac{1+u^2}{2}\right)}{(1-u^2)/2}\,u\cdot(-u)\,du
=-2\int_0^1 \frac{u^2}{1-u^2}\,\ln\!\left(\frac{1+u^2}{2}\right)\,du.
$$
Since $\frac{u^2}{1-u^2}=-1+\frac1{1-u^2}$,
$$
I=2\int_0^1 \ln\!\left(\frac{1+u^2}{2}\right)\,du
-2\int_0^1 \frac{\ln\!\left(\frac{1+u^2}{2}\right)}{1-u^2}\,du.
$$
But $\int_0^1 \ln\!\left(\frac{1+u^2}{2}\right)\,du=J=\frac{\pi}{2}-2$, so $2\int_0^1 \ln\!\left(\frac{1+u^2}{2}\right)\,du=\pi-4$. Therefore
$$
I=\pi-4-2K,
\quad
K:=\int_0^1 \frac{\ln\!\left(\frac{1+u^2}{2}\right)}{1-u^2}\,du.
$$
Hence
$$
S=I+4-\pi = (\pi-4-2K)+4-\pi = -2K.
$$

Now evaluate $K$ by $u=\tan\theta$, $\theta\in[0,\pi/4]$. Then
$$
1+u^2=\sec^2\theta,\quad 1-u^2=1-\tan^2\theta=\frac{\cos 2\theta}{\cos^2\theta},\quad du=\sec^2\theta\,d\theta,
$$
so
$$
K=\int_0^{\pi/4}\frac{\ln(\sec^2\theta/2)}{\cos 2\theta}\,d\theta.
$$
Let $x=2\theta$ ($x\in[0,\pi/2]$):
$$
K=\frac12\int_0^{\pi/2}\frac{\ln\!\left(\frac{1}{2\cos^2(x/2)}\right)}{\cos x}\,dx.
$$
But $2\cos^2(x/2)=1+\cos x$, so $\ln\!\left(\frac{1}{2\cos^2(x/2)}\right)=-\ln(1+\cos x)$. Thus
$$
K=-\frac12\int_0^{\pi/2}\frac{\ln(1+\cos x)}{\cos x}\,dx.
$$
With $x=\frac{\pi}{2}-\varphi$, $\cos x=\sin\varphi$, this becomes
$$
K=-\frac12\int_0^{\pi/2}\frac{\ln(1+\sin\varphi)}{\sin\varphi}\,d\varphi,
$$
so
$$
S=-2K=\int_0^{\pi/2}\frac{\ln(1+\sin\varphi)}{\sin\varphi}\,d\varphi.
$$

### 3) Evaluate the last integral
Use the tangent half-angle substitution $t=\tan(\varphi/2)$, so $\varphi\in[0,\pi/2]$ corresponds to $t\in[0,1]$, and
$$
\sin\varphi=\frac{2t}{1+t^2},\qquad d\varphi=\frac{2}{1+t^2}\,dt.
$$
Then
$$
S=\int_0^1 \frac{\ln\!\left(1+\frac{2t}{1+t^2}\right)}{\frac{2t}{1+t^2}}\cdot\frac{2}{1+t^2}\,dt
=\int_0^1 \frac{\ln\!\left(\frac{(t+1)^2}{1+t^2}\right)}{t}\,dt
=\int_0^1 \frac{2\ln(1+t)-\ln(1+t^2)}{t}\,dt.
$$
Split:
$$
S=2\int_0^1 \frac{\ln(1+t)}{t}\,dt-\int_0^1 \frac{\ln(1+t^2)}{t}\,dt.
$$
Expand (termwise integration is justified since $\sum_{n\ge1}\int_0^1 |t^{n-1}|/n\,dt=\sum 1/n^2<\infty$):
$$
\ln(1+t)=\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(-1)^{n+1}}{n}t^n
\quad\Rightarrow\quad
\int_0^1\frac{\ln(1+t)}{t}\,dt=\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(-1)^{n+1}}{n^2}.
$$
Similarly,
$$
\ln(1+t^2)=\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(-1)^{n+1}}{n}t^{2n}
\quad\Rightarrow\quad
\int_0^1\frac{\ln(1+t^2)}{t}\,dt=\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(-1)^{n+1}}{2n^2}.
$$
Let $\eta(2):=\sum_{n=1}^\infty (-1)^{n+1}/n^2$. It is well-known that $\eta(2)=(1-2^{1-2})\zeta(2)=\frac12\zeta(2)=\frac{\pi^2}{12}$ (using $\zeta(2)=\pi^2/6$). Hence
$$
\int_0^1\frac{\ln(1+t)}{t}\,dt=\frac{\pi^2}{12},
\qquad
\int_0^1\frac{\ln(1+t^2)}{t}\,dt=\frac12\cdot\frac{\pi^2}{12}=\frac{\pi^2}{24}.
$$
Therefore
$$
S=2\cdot\frac{\pi^2}{12}-\frac{\pi^2}{24}
=\frac{\pi^2}{6}-\frac{\pi^2}{24}
=\frac{3\pi^2}{24}
=\frac{\pi^2}{8}.
$$

$$
\boxed{\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{2^n}{n^2 \binom{2n}{n}}=\frac{\pi^2}{8}.}
$$

question:
Here is a challenging mathematics problem in the domain of approximations and expansions, designed to test asymptotic analysis skills.


Consider the integral $I(\lambda)$ defined by:
$$ I(\lambda) = \int_0^1 e^{\lambda(x^2 - x)} \ln x \, dx $$
for $\lambda > 0$.

Determine the asymptotic expansion of $I(\lambda)$ as $\lambda \to \infty$. Specifically, find the values of the constants $a, b, c,$ and $d$ in the expansion:
$$ I(\lambda) = a \frac{\ln \lambda}{\lambda} + \frac{b}{\lambda} + c \frac{\ln \lambda}{\lambda^2} + \frac{d}{\lambda^2} + o(\lambda^{-2}) $$
Express your answers in terms of the Euler-Mascheroni constant $\gamma$.

attempts.answer:
Write
$$
I(\lambda)=\int_0^1 e^{\lambda(x^2-x)}\ln x\,dx=\int_0^1 e^{-\lambda x(1-x)}\ln x\,dx,\qquad \lambda\to+\infty.
$$
Since $x(1-x)\ge \tfrac14$ on $[\tfrac12-\varepsilon,\tfrac12+\varepsilon]$, the contribution from any fixed neighborhood of $x=\tfrac12$ is $O(e^{-\lambda/4})$, hence negligible compared to any power $\lambda^{-N}$. Thus only boundary layers near $x=0$ and $x=1$ contribute to the algebraic expansion.

Split
$$
I(\lambda)=I_0(\lambda)+I_1(\lambda),\qquad 
I_0=\int_0^{1/2} e^{-\lambda x(1-x)}\ln x\,dx,\quad
I_1=\int_{1/2}^{1} e^{-\lambda x(1-x)}\ln x\,dx.
$$

## 1) Contribution near $x=0$
On $[0,\tfrac12]$, set $x=t/\lambda$. Then $dx=dt/\lambda$ and
$$
-\lambda x(1-x)= -t + \frac{t^2}{\lambda},
$$
so
$$
I_0(\lambda)=\frac1\lambda\int_0^{\lambda/2} e^{-t}e^{t^2/\lambda}\,(\ln t-\ln\lambda)\,dt.
$$
For $0\le t\le \lambda/2$, we have $-t+t^2/\lambda\le -t/2$, giving an integrable dominating function $e^{-t/2}(|\ln t|+|\ln\lambda|)$. Hence we may expand
$$
e^{t^2/\lambda}=1+\frac{t^2}{\lambda}+O(\lambda^{-2})
$$
inside the integral, with an $O(\lambda^{-2})$ remainder uniformly integrable on $[0,\lambda/2]$. Extending the upper limit to $\infty$ introduces only an exponentially small error $O(e^{-\lambda/4})$. Thus
$$
I_0(\lambda)=\frac1\lambda\int_0^{\infty} e^{-t}(\ln t-\ln\lambda)\,dt
+\frac1{\lambda^2}\int_0^{\infty} e^{-t}t^2(\ln t-\ln\lambda)\,dt
+o(\lambda^{-2}).
$$
Use the standard identities (with $\gamma$ Euler’s constant and $\psi$ the digamma function):
$$
\int_0^\infty e^{-t}\,dt=1,\qquad \int_0^\infty e^{-t}\ln t\,dt=\Gamma'(1)=-\gamma,
$$
$$
\int_0^\infty e^{-t}t^2\,dt=\Gamma(3)=2,\qquad 
\int_0^\infty e^{-t}t^2\ln t\,dt=\Gamma'(3)=\Gamma(3)\psi(3)=2\Bigl(\frac32-\gamma\Bigr)=3-2\gamma.
$$
Therefore
$$
I_0(\lambda)=\frac1\lambda\bigl(-\gamma-\ln\lambda\bigr)
+\frac1{\lambda^2}\bigl((3-2\gamma)-2\ln\lambda\bigr)
+o(\lambda^{-2}).
$$

## 2) Contribution near $x=1$
Let $y=1-x$ on $[1/2,1]$. Then $y\in[0,1/2]$, $dx=-dy$, and
$$
x^2-x=(1-y)^2-(1-y)=-y+y^2,
$$
so
$$
I_1(\lambda)=\int_0^{1/2} e^{-\lambda y+\lambda y^2}\,\ln(1-y)\,dy.
$$
Now scale $y=t/\lambda$:
$$
I_1(\lambda)=\frac1\lambda\int_0^{\lambda/2} e^{-t}e^{t^2/\lambda}\,\ln\Bigl(1-\frac{t}{\lambda}\Bigr)\,dt.
$$
Using $\ln(1-u)= -u+O(u^2)$ as $u\to0$, we get
$$
\ln\Bigl(1-\frac{t}{\lambda}\Bigr)= -\frac{t}{\lambda}+O(\lambda^{-2})
$$
uniformly for $0\le t\le \lambda/2$. Also $e^{t^2/\lambda}=1+O(1)$. Hence
$$
I_1(\lambda)=\frac1\lambda\int_0^{\lambda/2} e^{-t}\left(-\frac{t}{\lambda}\right)\,dt+O(\lambda^{-3})
= -\frac1{\lambda^2}\int_0^\infty t e^{-t}\,dt + o(\lambda^{-2})
= -\frac1{\lambda^2}+o(\lambda^{-2}),
$$
since $\int_0^\infty t e^{-t}\,dt=\Gamma(2)=1$.

## 3) Combine
Adding $I_0$ and $I_1$,
$$
I(\lambda)= -\frac{\ln\lambda}{\lambda}-\frac{\gamma}{\lambda}
-\frac{2\ln\lambda}{\lambda^2}+\frac{(3-2\gamma)-1}{\lambda^2}+o(\lambda^{-2})
= -\frac{\ln\lambda}{\lambda}-\frac{\gamma}{\lambda}
-\frac{2\ln\lambda}{\lambda^2}+\frac{2-2\gamma}{\lambda^2}+o(\lambda^{-2}).
$$

Therefore, in
$$
I(\lambda)=a\frac{\ln\lambda}{\lambda}+\frac{b}{\lambda}+c\frac{\ln\lambda}{\lambda^2}+\frac{d}{\lambda^2}+o(\lambda^{-2}),
$$
the constants are
$$
\boxed{a=-1,\quad b=-\gamma,\quad c=-2,\quad d=2-2\gamma.}
$$
attempts.raw_answer:
Write
\[
I(\lambda)=\int_0^1 e^{\lambda(x^2-x)}\ln x\,dx=\int_0^1 e^{-\lambda x(1-x)}\ln x\,dx,\qquad \lambda\to+\infty.
\]
Since \(x(1-x)\ge \tfrac14\) on \([\tfrac12-\varepsilon,\tfrac12+\varepsilon]\), the contribution from any fixed neighborhood of \(x=\tfrac12\) is \(O(e^{-\lambda/4})\), hence negligible compared to any power \(\lambda^{-N}\). Thus only boundary layers near \(x=0\) and \(x=1\) contribute to the algebraic expansion.

Split
\[
I(\lambda)=I_0(\lambda)+I_1(\lambda),\qquad 
I_0=\int_0^{1/2} e^{-\lambda x(1-x)}\ln x\,dx,\quad
I_1=\int_{1/2}^{1} e^{-\lambda x(1-x)}\ln x\,dx.
\]

## 1) Contribution near \(x=0\)
On \([0,\tfrac12]\), set \(x=t/\lambda\). Then \(dx=dt/\lambda\) and
\[
-\lambda x(1-x)= -t + \frac{t^2}{\lambda},
\]
so
\[
I_0(\lambda)=\frac1\lambda\int_0^{\lambda/2} e^{-t}e^{t^2/\lambda}\,(\ln t-\ln\lambda)\,dt.
\]
For \(0\le t\le \lambda/2\), we have \(-t+t^2/\lambda\le -t/2\), giving an integrable dominating function \(e^{-t/2}(|\ln t|+|\ln\lambda|)\). Hence we may expand
\[
e^{t^2/\lambda}=1+\frac{t^2}{\lambda}+O(\lambda^{-2})
\]
inside the integral, with an \(O(\lambda^{-2})\) remainder uniformly integrable on \([0,\lambda/2]\). Extending the upper limit to \(\infty\) introduces only an exponentially small error \(O(e^{-\lambda/4})\). Thus
\[
I_0(\lambda)=\frac1\lambda\int_0^{\infty} e^{-t}(\ln t-\ln\lambda)\,dt
+\frac1{\lambda^2}\int_0^{\infty} e^{-t}t^2(\ln t-\ln\lambda)\,dt
+o(\lambda^{-2}).
\]
Use the standard identities (with \(\gamma\) Euler’s constant and \(\psi\) the digamma function):
\[
\int_0^\infty e^{-t}\,dt=1,\qquad \int_0^\infty e^{-t}\ln t\,dt=\Gamma'(1)=-\gamma,
\]
\[
\int_0^\infty e^{-t}t^2\,dt=\Gamma(3)=2,\qquad 
\int_0^\infty e^{-t}t^2\ln t\,dt=\Gamma'(3)=\Gamma(3)\psi(3)=2\Bigl(\frac32-\gamma\Bigr)=3-2\gamma.
\]
Therefore
\[
I_0(\lambda)=\frac1\lambda\bigl(-\gamma-\ln\lambda\bigr)
+\frac1{\lambda^2}\bigl((3-2\gamma)-2\ln\lambda\bigr)
+o(\lambda^{-2}).
\]

## 2) Contribution near \(x=1\)
Let \(y=1-x\) on \([1/2,1]\). Then \(y\in[0,1/2]\), \(dx=-dy\), and
\[
x^2-x=(1-y)^2-(1-y)=-y+y^2,
\]
so
\[
I_1(\lambda)=\int_0^{1/2} e^{-\lambda y+\lambda y^2}\,\ln(1-y)\,dy.
\]
Now scale \(y=t/\lambda\):
\[
I_1(\lambda)=\frac1\lambda\int_0^{\lambda/2} e^{-t}e^{t^2/\lambda}\,\ln\Bigl(1-\frac{t}{\lambda}\Bigr)\,dt.
\]
Using \(\ln(1-u)= -u+O(u^2)\) as \(u\to0\), we get
\[
\ln\Bigl(1-\frac{t}{\lambda}\Bigr)= -\frac{t}{\lambda}+O(\lambda^{-2})
\]
uniformly for \(0\le t\le \lambda/2\). Also \(e^{t^2/\lambda}=1+O(1)\). Hence
\[
I_1(\lambda)=\frac1\lambda\int_0^{\lambda/2} e^{-t}\left(-\frac{t}{\lambda}\right)\,dt+O(\lambda^{-3})
= -\frac1{\lambda^2}\int_0^\infty t e^{-t}\,dt + o(\lambda^{-2})
= -\frac1{\lambda^2}+o(\lambda^{-2}),
\]
since \(\int_0^\infty t e^{-t}\,dt=\Gamma(2)=1\).

## 3) Combine
Adding \(I_0\) and \(I_1\),
\[
I(\lambda)= -\frac{\ln\lambda}{\lambda}-\frac{\gamma}{\lambda}
-\frac{2\ln\lambda}{\lambda^2}+\frac{(3-2\gamma)-1}{\lambda^2}+o(\lambda^{-2})
= -\frac{\ln\lambda}{\lambda}-\frac{\gamma}{\lambda}
-\frac{2\ln\lambda}{\lambda^2}+\frac{2-2\gamma}{\lambda^2}+o(\lambda^{-2}).
\]

Therefore, in
\[
I(\lambda)=a\frac{\ln\lambda}{\lambda}+\frac{b}{\lambda}+c\frac{\ln\lambda}{\lambda^2}+\frac{d}{\lambda^2}+o(\lambda^{-2}),
\]
the constants are
\[
\boxed{a=-1,\quad b=-\gamma,\quad c=-2,\quad d=2-2\gamma.}
\]

issues: The key step in the $x\to0$ boundary-layer analysis claims a Taylor expansion $e^{t^2/\lambda}=1+t^2/\lambda+O(\lambda^{-2})$ can be inserted uniformly for $0\le t\le \lambda/2$ with a uniformly integrable remainder. This is not justified and, as stated, is false: for $t\sim \lambda/2$, $t^2/\lambda\sim \lambda/4$ is not small, so the Taylor remainder is not $O(\lambda^{-2})$ uniformly on that interval.

Relatedly, extending the upper limit from $\lambda/2$ to $\infty$ and simultaneously expanding the integrand requires a careful truncation argument (e.g., split $t\in[0,\lambda^\alpha]$ and $t\in[\lambda^\alpha,\infty)$). The answer asserts this with a domination argument that does not actually control the Taylor remainder of $e^{t^2/\lambda}$.

Because the above justification is incomplete, the derivation of the $\lambda^{-2}$ coefficients from the $x\to0$ endpoint is not fully rigorous in the presented form, even if the final constants are likely correct.
evaluation.improvements: Make the endpoint expansion rigorous by localizing the $t$-integral to a region where $t^2/\lambda\ll 1$. For example: (1) after $x=t/\lambda$, split $\int_0^{\lambda/2}=\int_0^{\lambda^{\alpha}}+\int_{\lambda^{\alpha}}^{\lambda/2}$ with any $0<\alpha<1/2$; (2) on $[0,\lambda^{\alpha}]$, use Taylor with an explicit remainder bound $e^{t^2/\lambda}=1+t^2/\lambda+O(t^4/\lambda^2)$ and dominate by $e^{-t}(1+t^4)(|\ln t|+\ln\lambda)$ to justify termwise integration; (3) show the tail $t\ge \lambda^{\alpha}$ is exponentially small (e.g., bounded by $\int_{\lambda^{\alpha}}^{\infty} e^{-t/2}(\cdots)dt$) and hence $o(\lambda^{-2})$; (4) then extend the truncated upper limit to $\infty$ legitimately. With these fixes, the stated constants $a=-1,b=-\gamma,c=-2,d=2-2\gamma$ can be concluded rigorously.

attempts.answer:
Write
\[
I(\lambda)=\int_0^1 e^{\lambda(x^2-x)}\ln x\,dx=\int_0^1 e^{-\lambda x(1-x)}\ln x\,dx,\qquad \lambda\to+\infty.
\]
Fix \(\delta\in(0,\tfrac12)\). On \([\delta,1-\delta]\) we have \(x(1-x)\ge \delta(1-\delta)=:m>0\), hence
\[
\int_\delta^{1-\delta} e^{-\lambda x(1-x)}|\ln x|\,dx \le e^{-m\lambda}\int_\delta^{1-\delta}|\ln x|\,dx=O(e^{-m\lambda}),
\]
which is \(o(\lambda^{-N})\) for every \(N\). Thus only the endpoint layers \([0,\delta]\) and \([1-\delta,1]\) contribute to the algebraic expansion.

Define
\[
I_0(\lambda):=\int_0^\delta e^{-\lambda x(1-x)}\ln x\,dx,\qquad
I_1(\lambda):=\int_{1-\delta}^1 e^{-\lambda x(1-x)}\ln x\,dx.
\]

## 1) Endpoint \(x=0\)
Substitute \(x=t/\lambda\) (so \(dx=dt/\lambda\)) to get
\[
I_0(\lambda)=\frac1\lambda\int_0^{\delta\lambda} e^{-t+t^2/\lambda}\,(\ln t-\ln\lambda)\,dt.
\]
Fix any \(\alpha\in(0,\tfrac12)\) and split
\[
\int_0^{\delta\lambda}=\int_0^{\lambda^\alpha}+\int_{\lambda^\alpha}^{\delta\lambda}=:J_{0,1}+J_{0,2}.
\]

### Tail \(J_{0,2}\)
For \(t\le \delta\lambda\) we have \(t^2/\lambda\le \delta t\), hence \(-t+t^2/\lambda\le -(1-\delta)t\). Therefore
\[
|J_{0,2}|\le \int_{\lambda^\alpha}^{\infty} e^{-(1-\delta)t}\, (|\ln t|+\ln\lambda)\,dt
=O\!\big((\ln\lambda)e^{-(1-\delta)\lambda^\alpha}\big),
\]
so \(\frac1\lambda J_{0,2}=o(\lambda^{-2})\).

### Main part \(J_{0,1}\)
On \(0\le t\le \lambda^\alpha\), \(u:=t^2/\lambda\) satisfies \(|u|\le \lambda^{2\alpha-1}\to 0\). Using
\[
e^{u}=1+u+R(u),\qquad |R(u)|\le C u^2 \quad (|u|\le 1)
\]
for some constant \(C\), we get for large \(\lambda\),
\[
e^{t^2/\lambda}=1+\frac{t^2}{\lambda}+O\!\left(\frac{t^4}{\lambda^2}\right)\qquad (0\le t\le \lambda^\alpha).
\]
Thus
\[
\frac1\lambda J_{0,1}
=\frac1\lambda\int_0^{\lambda^\alpha} e^{-t}(\ln t-\ln\lambda)\,dt
+\frac1{\lambda^2}\int_0^{\lambda^\alpha} e^{-t}t^2(\ln t-\ln\lambda)\,dt
+R_0(\lambda),
\]
where
\[
|R_0(\lambda)|\le \frac{C}{\lambda^3}\int_0^{\lambda^\alpha} e^{-t}t^4(|\ln t|+\ln\lambda)\,dt
=O(\lambda^{-3}\ln\lambda)=o(\lambda^{-2}),
\]
since \(\int_0^\infty e^{-t}t^4(|\ln t|+1)\,dt<\infty\).

Now extend the upper limit \(\lambda^\alpha\) to \(\infty\): the error is \(O((\ln\lambda)e^{-\lambda^\alpha})\), hence contributes \(o(\lambda^{-2})\) after multiplying by \(\lambda^{-1}\) or \(\lambda^{-2}\). Therefore
\[
I_0(\lambda)=\frac1\lambda\int_0^{\infty} e^{-t}(\ln t-\ln\lambda)\,dt
+\frac1{\lambda^2}\int_0^{\infty} e^{-t}t^2(\ln t-\ln\lambda)\,dt
+o(\lambda^{-2}).
\]
Using
\[
\int_0^\infty e^{-t}\,dt=1,\quad \int_0^\infty e^{-t}\ln t\,dt=\Gamma'(1)=-\gamma,
\]
\[
\int_0^\infty e^{-t}t^2\,dt=\Gamma(3)=2,\quad
\int_0^\infty e^{-t}t^2\ln t\,dt=\Gamma'(3)=\Gamma(3)\psi(3)=2\Bigl(\frac32-\gamma\Bigr)=3-2\gamma,
\]
we obtain
\[
I_0(\lambda)=\frac1\lambda(-\gamma-\ln\lambda)+\frac1{\lambda^2}\bigl((3-2\gamma)-2\ln\lambda\bigr)+o(\lambda^{-2}).
\]

## 2) Endpoint \(x=1\)
Let \(y=1-x\). Then on \([1-\delta,1]\), \(y\in[0,\delta]\) and
\[
x^2-x=(1-y)^2-(1-y)=-y+y^2,
\]
so
\[
I_1(\lambda)=\int_0^\delta e^{-\lambda y+\lambda y^2}\,\ln(1-y)\,dy.
\]
Scale \(y=t/\lambda\):
\[
I_1(\lambda)=\frac1\lambda\int_0^{\delta\lambda} e^{-t+t^2/\lambda}\,\ln\!\Bigl(1-\frac{t}{\lambda}\Bigr)\,dt.
\]
Split again at \(t=\lambda^\alpha\) with \(\alpha\in(0,\tfrac12)\). As before, the tail \(t\ge \lambda^\alpha\) is exponentially small, hence \(o(\lambda^{-2})\).

On \(0\le t\le \lambda^\alpha\),
\[
\ln\!\Bigl(1-\frac{t}{\lambda}\Bigr)=-\frac{t}{\lambda}+O\!\left(\frac{t^2}{\lambda^2}\right),
\qquad
e^{t^2/\lambda}=1+O\!\left(\frac{t^2}{\lambda}\right),
\]
so
\[
e^{-t+t^2/\lambda}\ln\!\Bigl(1-\frac{t}{\lambda}\Bigr)
=e^{-t}\left(-\frac{t}{\lambda}\right)+O\!\left(e^{-t}\frac{t^3}{\lambda^2}\right).
\]
Therefore
\[
I_1(\lambda)= -\frac1{\lambda^2}\int_0^{\infty} t e^{-t}\,dt + o(\lambda^{-2})
= -\frac1{\lambda^2}+o(\lambda^{-2}),
\]
since \(\int_0^\infty t e^{-t}\,dt=\Gamma(2)=1\).

## 3) Combine
Since the interior contribution is \(O(e^{-m\lambda})\),
\[
I(\lambda)=I_0(\lambda)+I_1(\lambda)+O(e^{-m\lambda})
= -\frac{\ln\lambda}{\lambda}-\frac{\gamma}{\lambda}
-\frac{2\ln\lambda}{\lambda^2}+\frac{2-2\gamma}{\lambda^2}
+o(\lambda^{-2}).
\]
Thus in
\[
I(\lambda)=a\frac{\ln\lambda}{\lambda}+\frac{b}{\lambda}+c\frac{\ln\lambda}{\lambda^2}+\frac{d}{\lambda^2}+o(\lambda^{-2}),
\]
the constants are
\[
\boxed{a=-1,\qquad b=-\gamma,\qquad c=-2,\qquad d=2-2\gamma.}
\]
